questions.explanation: When stopped for a traffic violation or at an equipment check, the driver is responsible for producing their license, proof of registration, and proof of insurance. Drivers are required to have all three of these documents in a vehicle when it is being driven.

questions.question: A person who drives much slower than the speed limit:
questions.answerA: Is a very safe driver.
questions.answerB: Always has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Should not let following cars pass.
questions.answerD: May create a dangerous driving environment.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop Sign Ahead.
questions.answerB: Side Road.
questions.answerC: Railroad Warning.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a stop sign is ahead.

questions.question: When passing, you should move back into the right lane when:
questions.answerA: You are one vehicle length ahead of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerB: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: You are 50 feet ahead of the passed vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not pass unless you have enough space to return to the driving lane. Before you return to the driving lane, be sure you have enough room between yourself and the vehicle you have passed. When you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: Which of the following factors affect an individual's absorption of alcohol?
questions.answerA: Weight
questions.answerB: Height
questions.answerC: Intelligence
questions.explanation: Factors affecting a person's absorption of alcohol include the person's weight, their biological sex, the amount of food in their digestive tract, and the number of alcoholic beverages they have consumed. The only thing to do to remove alcohol from a person's system is to wait.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Pass the vehicle as slowly as possible.
questions.answerB: Drive at the same speed as the vehicle you are passing.
questions.answerC: Pass the vehicle as safely and as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle that is traveling in the same direction as you, pass quickly to resume visibility. Return to your previous lane only when you can see both of the vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: When backing up, drivers should drive at a speed:
questions.answerA: No faster than a slow crawl.
questions.answerB: No faster than a slow walk.
questions.answerC: No faster than a jog.
questions.explanation: When driving in reverse, you should move no faster than the speed of a slow walk. Vehicles are much more difficult to control when moving backwards.

questions.question: To help others see you when daylight begins to fade, you should use your:
questions.answerA: Parking lights.
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Emergency flashers.
questions.explanation: As daylight begins to fade, turn on your low beams to help others see you. Only use your high beam headlights in an open area where no other drivers are present.

questions.question: At a four-way stop:
questions.answerA: The driver to arrive first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The driver to arrive last has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: One driver should continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerD: One driver should wave the other drivers ahead.
questions.explanation: At four-way stops, traffic from all four directions must stop. The first vehicle to reach the intersection should move forward first. If two vehicles reach the intersection at the same time, the driver on the left yields to the driver on the right.

questions.question: How far down the road should you look when driving?
questions.answerA: 10 to 15 seconds.
questions.answerB: 100 to 150 yards.
questions.answerC: One to two blocks.
questions.explanation: You should stay aware of conditions on the road ahead in order to avoid the need for any last-second maneuvers. Looking 10 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle is a good habit.

questions.question: You must stop at an intersection when you see a:
questions.answerA: Flashing red light.
questions.answerB: Steady yellow light.
questions.answerC: Yellow arrow.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. At an intersection with a flashing red light, you must come to a complete stop, look both ways, and proceed only after the intersection is clear.

questions.question: This is the shape and color of a ____ sign.
questions.answerA: Stop
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Yield
questions.explanation: Downward-facing triangular signs mean drivers must yield. When approaching a yield sign, slow down to a speed that is reasonable for existing conditions and stop if necessary. If you must stop, do so at a marked stop line, if it exists.

questions.question: You have to report a crash to law enforcement when:
questions.answerA: Someone is hurt.
questions.answerB: The damage is more than $1,000.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: A crash must be reported to law enforcement if it results in any deaths, injuries, or $1,000 or more in property damage (or $200 or more in damage to non-vehicle government property, such as signs or guardrails).

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Road widens ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane reduction. The right lane ends soon and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerC: Highway entrance ramp ahead.
questions.explanation: A warning sign is usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns that the number of lanes ahead is reduced and that traffic will need to merge to the left.

questions.question: Which of the following commonly causes traffic accidents?
questions.answerA: Inattentive driving
questions.answerB: Excessive speed under the driving conditions
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles too closely
questions.explanation: Driving too fast for conditions is a major cause of motor vehicle crashes. Being inattentive to surroundings can cause a driver to collide with other vehicles. Most rear-end collisions are caused by drivers following other vehicles too closely.

questions.question: When approaching an accident scene, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your attention on your driving.
questions.answerB: Keep moving.
questions.answerC: Stop if you are involved or if emergency help has not yet arrived.
questions.explanation: Do not stop at an accident scene unless you are involved or emergency help has not yet arrived. Keep your attention on your driving and keep moving, watching for people who might be on or near the road. Never drive to the scene of an accident, fire, or other disaster just to look.

questions.question: Children on bicycles should be given extra space by motor vehicle operators because:
questions.answerA: They do not have the same physical reflexes as adults.
questions.answerB: They are smaller and more difficult to see than adults.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Children are often the least predictable pedestrians and the most difficult pedestrians to see. Take extra care to look out for children, especially near schools, bus stops, playgrounds, parks, and ice cream trucks. Be aware of children riding bikes on the sidewalk, as they may come onto the road unexpectedly.

questions.question: An inattentive driver is a driver who:
questions.answerA: Stares at objects off the roadway or daydreams while driving.
questions.answerB: Maintains eye contact during a conversation with a passenger while driving.
questions.answerC: Only watches the vehicle ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not become distracted by looking at passengers, attempting to find something in your vehicle, looking at reading material, sightseeing, or daydreaming while driving. Continue scanning the road, checking your mirrors, and looking at the instrument panel at regular intervals. Developing these safe habits will keep you attentive as a driver.

questions.question: If you come to an intersection controlled by a flashing yellow light, you must:
questions.answerA: Wait for the green light before proceeding.
questions.answerB: Slow down and cross the intersection carefully.
questions.answerC: Stop before crossing the intersection.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow traffic light means drivers must slow down, be more aware, and proceed with caution. Be alert to crossing traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: Pennant-shaped signs indicate:
questions.answerA: School zones.
questions.answerB: No passing zones.
questions.answerC: Speed limits.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped signs usually indicate no passing zones. Text will also be on the sign to confirm that it is a no passing zone.

questions.question: The consumption of alcohol while taking drugs can:
questions.answerA: Decrease the effects of the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerB: Increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol.
questions.answerC: Help cure your illness.
questions.explanation: The combination of alcohol and drugs, in some cases, can increase the effects of both the drugs and alcohol. It can be unsafe to drive after consuming either alcohol or drugs and is even more dangerous after combining them.

questions.question: ____ limit your concentration, perception, judgment, and memory.
questions.answerA: Only a blood alcohol level greater than the legal limit can
questions.answerB: Alcohol does not
questions.answerC: Even the smallest amount of alcohol can
questions.answerD: Only a blood alcohol level greater than 0.05 percent can
questions.explanation: Even the smallest amount of alcohol will reduce your concentration, perception, judgment and memory, and your driving skills will suffer. No one can drink and drive safely.

questions.question: An intersection has no traffic signs or signals. You arrive at the same time as a vehicle to your right. You should:
questions.answerA: Speed up and get through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Slow down and yield to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Drive into the intersection and make the other vehicle stop.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn and drive through the intersection.
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. Once the vehicle on the right has safely passed through the intersection, the other driver may proceed.

questions.question: You have allowed the wheels of your vehicle to run off the edge of the pavement. What should you do first?
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels slightly to the left to edge the car back onto the pavement.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes and turn the front wheels sharply to the left.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle leaves the roadway, hold the steering wheel firmly, release the gas pedal, and gently apply the brakes. Wait until your speed has reduced, check the traffic, and look for a place to safely return to the roadway by merging back into traffic. Overcompensating by jerking the wheel to return to the roadway can cause you to lose control of your vehicle or may cause your car to go into other lanes of traffic.

questions.question: When parallel parking between two cars, you should first:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerC: Pull up even with the car in front of your desired parking space.
questions.explanation: After finding a parking space, checking traffic, and signaling, you should stop parallel to the vehicle directly ahead of your desired parking space before turning your wheel to park.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way road.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: Exit.
questions.answerD: Sharp right turn in the road ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a sharp right turn ahead.

questions.question: Before changing lanes on a multilane highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn.
questions.answerB: Turn on your headlights.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, you should look in your rearview and side mirrors to make sure no one is trying to pass you. You should also look over your shoulder to make sure that no one is in your blind spot.

questions.question: The most important thing to remember about speed management and curves is that you must:
questions.answerA: Drive at the posted speed limit as you enter the curve, then slow down at the sharpest part of the curve.
questions.answerB: Slow down before you enter the curve.
questions.answerC: Accelerate gently before you enter the curve.
questions.answerD: Drive at the posted speed limit before, throughout, and after the curve.
questions.explanation: The most important thing to remember about driving in curves is that your vehicle’s inertia may make it difficult to turn. To maintain control, it is essential that you slow down before entering the curve.

questions.question: This bicyclist is signaling:
questions.answerA: A left turn.
questions.answerB: An upcoming stop.
questions.answerC: A right turn.
questions.explanation: Bicycles do not have turn signals so bicyclists use hand and arm signals to alert other drivers to their intentions. If a bicyclist puts their left arm straight out, they are signaling that they intend to turn left.

questions.question: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the:
questions.answerA: Road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Presence of a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Use of your turn signals.
questions.explanation: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If you want to pass a pedestrian who is walking along the roadway and an oncoming vehicle is approaching, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and let the oncoming vehicle pass before you pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerB: Keep driving at a steady speed. The oncoming vehicle must stop for you.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn to get the pedestrian to move over.
questions.explanation: If possible, try to only deal with one roadway hazard at a time. If you want to pass a pedestrian but an oncoming vehicle is approaching, slow down and let the vehicle pass. You may then pass the pedestrian if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Seat belts are most effective when they are worn by:
questions.answerA: The person driving the car.
questions.answerB: Passengers when they are on a long drive.
questions.answerC: All occupants of a car being driven on an expressway.
questions.answerD: All occupants of a car every time the car is driven.
questions.explanation: When you drive, make sure each person in your vehicle wears a seat belt. In the event of a crash, a person without a seat belt becomes a flying object and a danger to each person in the vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Emergency vehicles ahead.
questions.answerB: Uncontrolled intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Four-way stop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a traffic signal is ahead.

questions.question: You are approaching a green traffic light and traffic is blocking the intersection. What is the best thing to do?
questions.answerA: Partially enter the intersection to establish your right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Don't enter the intersection until you can get completely across.
questions.answerC: Continue into the intersection and wait for traffic to clear.
questions.explanation: Even if your light is green, you must not enter an intersection unless you can get completely through the intersection before the light turns red. If you block the intersection, you can be cited.

questions.question: You are driving on the freeway behind a large truck. You should drive:
questions.answerA: Closer behind the truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Farther behind the truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: To the right side of the truck and wait to pass.
questions.explanation: It is necessary to follow farther behind a large truck than you would if following a passenger vehicle because trucks have larger blind spots.

questions.question: On a freeway, you should look farther ahead than you would on a city street:
questions.answerA: In order to see potential hazards early.
questions.answerB: Because it takes a quarter of a mile to stop your vehicle completely.
questions.answerC: Because it helps you keep up with traffic.
questions.explanation: On the freeway, be ready for changes in traffic conditions. Watch for signals from other drivers. Expect merging vehicles at on-ramps and interchanges and be prepared for rapid changes in road conditions and traffic flow.

questions.question: What should you do if your accelerator sticks while you are driving?
questions.answerA: Reach down and attempt to pull it up.
questions.answerB: Shift to park.
questions.answerC: Shift to neutral and apply steady pressure on the brake.
questions.explanation: If your accelerator sticks while you are driving, keep your eyes on the road. Quickly shift the vehicle into neutral and apply steady pressure on the brake pedal. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so and turn off the engine.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of driving hours an applicant under age 18 must complete before applying for a probationary license?
questions.answerA: 50 hours total, including 10 at night
questions.answerB: 40 hours total, including 10 at night
questions.answerC: 30 hours total, including 10 at night
questions.explanation: To obtain a probationary license, an applicant under the age of 18 must have accumulated 30 hours of behind-the-wheel driving experience. 10 of those hours must have been completed at night.

questions.question: When two vehicles arrive to an intersection at the same time, which one has the right-of-way when no signs or signals indicate rules?
questions.answerA: The car approaching from the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car approaching from the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car in which the driver sounds his horn first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: The car that is traveling the fastest has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: At an intersection of two similar roads without a traffic control device, a driver must yield to a vehicle approaching from the right.

questions.question: If you approach a flashing red traffic light, you:
questions.answerA: Are traveling in the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: Must treat the intersection as if it is controlled by a stop sign.
questions.answerC: May not proceed until it changes to green.
questions.explanation: Treat a flashing red light the same as a stop sign. Come to a complete stop at the stop line or, if there is no stop line, prior to the crosswalk and before entering the intersection. Yield to all other traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: If you are driving and a tire suddenly goes flat, you should:
questions.answerA: Rapidly pump the brake pedal several times.
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and not brake.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake pedal as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: If a tire blows out or suddenly goes flat while you are driving, grip the steering wheel firmly and keep the vehicle aiming straight. Take your foot off the accelerator and do not brake. Allow the vehicle to slow by itself and use the brakes gently, but only if necessary. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about railroad crossings is true?
questions.answerA: It is against the law to go around lowered gates at a crossing.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger.
questions.answerC: Not all railroad crossings are equipped with flashing red signals and gates.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning devices, such as gates or flashing lights. Not all railroad crossings are equipped with such devices. It is against the law to drive around lowered railroad crossing gates.

questions.question: Signaling your intentions before turning, changing lanes, or driving away from a curb:
questions.answerA: Is necessary only if other traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Is a good driving habit and is required by law.
questions.answerC: Is necessary only during the maneuver, not before.
questions.answerD: Is not necessary if the maneuver is done slowly.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes or turning, signal your intentions well in advance. The law requires that you signal for at least 100 feet before you move your vehicle to the right or left. Before pulling away from a curb, always signal to inform passing drivers of your intentions.

questions.question: To prevent hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.answerB: Ensure that your tires are properly inflated.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed when driving in the rain.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, you should ensure that the tires on your vehicle have good tread depth and are inflated to the proper pressure. Reduce the speed of your vehicle when driving in the rain. Hydroplaning occurs most frequently at higher speeds.

questions.question: You may continue carefully through an intersection with a yellow light if:
questions.answerA: There is an emergency vehicle crossing your lane.
questions.answerB: There are pedestrians crossing.
questions.answerC: You are turning right.
questions.answerD: You are already within the intersection when the light changes to yellow.
questions.explanation: If a steady yellow light appears when you are already within an intersection, you should continue through the intersection carefully.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Heavy traffic ahead.
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign means that it is not safe for drivers to enter the indicated road or driveway from their current direction. If you come across one of these signs, you should immediately turn around and drive a different way.

questions.question: This sign indicates that:
questions.answerA: There is a steep hill ahead.
questions.answerB: No trucks are allowed on the upcoming hill.
questions.answerC: A logging road is ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming steep hill. Drivers should slow down and be ready to control their speed and protect their brakes from damage.

questions.question: When you drive through a construction zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to watch the workers.
questions.answerB: Decrease your following distance.
questions.answerC: Pass the construction zone carefully and not “rubberneck."
questions.explanation: To avoid contributing to chronic traffic congestion, you should not "rubberneck." That is, you should not slow down to look at out-of-the-ordinary things.

questions.question: Crossbuck signs indicate:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossings.
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: No passing zones.
questions.explanation: Crossbuck signs tell drivers to yield to trains at a railroad crossing. Drivers should not try to outdrive a train.

questions.question: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver:
questions.answerA: Relax and concentrate on driving.
questions.answerB: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Tailgate the driver in front of you.
questions.explanation: To prevent yourself from becoming an aggressive driver, concentrate on driving and don't take the actions of other drivers personally. Be realistic about your travel time, drive within posted speed limits, and be forgiving of other drivers using the roadway.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: The maximum speed limit under ideal conditions is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must not travel below the speed indicated.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. This particular sign tells you the maximum speed limit for the stretch of highway where it is posted. You may drive more slowly than the posted speed limit, based on road conditions, but it is illegal to drive any faster than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: When you are facing a green light and there are pedestrians in the intersection:
questions.answerA: You must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way over pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must wait for you to cross.
questions.explanation: When facing a green light, you must yield to pedestrians and vehicles already in the intersection. Drivers must yield to pedestrians when turning on a steady green signal.

questions.question: To check your blind spot before changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Look into the left side mirror.
questions.answerB: Look into the right side mirror.
questions.answerC: Look into the rearview mirror.
questions.answerD: Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move.
questions.explanation: To check your blind spot before changing lanes, you should look over your shoulder in the direction that you plan to move.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross the street after the "Don't Walk" signal begins to flash. The pedestrian is in the middle of the street when your signal light changes to green. You should:
questions.answerA: Proceed if you have the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Proceed if the pedestrian is not in your lane.
questions.answerC: Wait until the pedestrian crosses the street before proceeding.
questions.explanation: At a green light, you must give the right-of-way to any vehicle, bicyclist, or pedestrian in the intersection. If a pedestrian begins crossing the street after the traffic signal light starts flashing, wait until they have crossed the street before proceeding.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing warning sign:
questions.answerA: Be ready to drive faster than the train.
questions.answerB: Be prepared to stop if a train is nearby.
questions.answerC: Look for a way around any lowered gates.
questions.answerD: Assume no trains are nearby and continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossing warning signs are used to warn drivers of the possibility of a train. Drivers should obey all railroad crossing warning signs and never go around barriers or disregard the warning sign.

questions.question: When you want to change lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Move into another lane while within an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spot by looking over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: You should never change lanes within an intersection. Before changing lanes, always look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. Be alert to other drivers moving into the same lane.

questions.question: This yellow warning sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching a school or school crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Slow down, drive with caution, and watch for children.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: This sign is placed on roads near schools to warn drivers to slow down, drive with caution, and watch for children.

questions.question: When should you yield your legal right-of-way?
questions.answerA: Often, even at controlled intersections.
questions.answerB: Whenever it helps prevent collisions.
questions.answerC: Never. It confuses other drivers.
questions.explanation: Never assume other drivers will give you the right-of-way. Yield your right-of-way whenever it helps prevent collisions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Cars on the right move first.
questions.answerB: You have the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Let cross traffic pass before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When approaching this sign, you must yield the right-of-way. Slow down and let vehicles and pedestrians crossing your path pass before you proceed. If necessary, stop before going ahead.

questions.question: The law requires you to stay at least how far behind an active snowplow with its red or amber lights on?
questions.answerA: 200 feet
questions.answerB: 300 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: On roads with a posted speed limit of 35 mph or more, the law requires drivers to stay at least 200 feet behind a working snowplow when its red or amber lights are on.

questions.question: You may drive around or under a gate that is being lowered or raised at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: As long as an approaching train is not too close.
questions.answerB: If your vehicle can do so without damaging the gate.
questions.answerC: If you first look carefully in both directions.
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights, lowered crossing gates, and/or bells at a railroad crossing mean that you must come to a complete stop. You must not go across the tracks until the lights and bells have stopped and the crossing gates are completely up. Do not drive around or under a gate that is moving up or down.

questions.question: Your first response to reduced visibility should be:
questions.answerA: Turning on your headlights.
questions.answerB: Reducing your speed.
questions.answerC: Turning on your windshield wipers.
questions.answerD: Looking for road edge markings to guide you.
questions.explanation: Reducing your speed should be your first response to decreased visibility and dangerous road conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You must drive slowly and sound your horn.
questions.answerB: A bus stop is ahead.
questions.answerC: You are entering a school's parking lot.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching a school zone and that they should slow down and watch for children.

questions.question: What does a single dashed yellow line separating traffic mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers may pass if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerB: Both lanes travel in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not pass.
questions.answerD: Drivers may pass, even if it could be dangerous.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions. A single dashed yellow line in the center of a road indicates that vehicles traveling in both directions are permitted to pass. Drivers may only begin a pass if they will not interfere with any oncoming traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Roundabout ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane ends, merge left.
questions.answerC: Turn around.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a roundabout is ahead. Enter a roundabout at a low speed and yield to existing traffic.

questions.question: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you:
questions.answerA: May still turn, but you must yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: May no longer turn and must proceed straight.
questions.answerC: Still have the right-of-way to turn.
questions.answerD: No longer have to turn in the direction that the arrow indicated.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow turns into a solid green light, you may still turn in the direction that the arrow was pointing but you must first yield to pedestrians and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: When you see this black and yellow sign, it means:
questions.answerA: The road to the right is for one-way traffic only.
questions.answerB: There is a detour to the right due to road construction.
questions.answerC: The road ahead changes direction at an extreme angle.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign tells drivers to slow down and prepare for an abrupt change in direction at an extreme angle.

questions.question: Increasing your vehicle’s speed:
questions.answerA: Increases your field of vision.
questions.answerB: Decreases your field of vision.
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to see cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your field of vision.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive, the smaller your field of vision becomes. As your speed increases and your field of vision decreases, you must be extra alert to potential hazards.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerB: Flagger ahead.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to an upcoming intersection.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you:
questions.answerA: Must yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Must yield to vehicles only on your right.
questions.answerC: Should slow down but never stop.
questions.explanation: When approaching a yield sign, drivers must give the right-of-way to traffic already in the lanes that they intend to enter or cross. Drivers should be prepared to stop when approaching a yield sign but may continue without stopping if there is no conflicting traffic.

questions.question: Fog can greatly reduce the visibility of other vehicles, pedestrians, and traffic signals. When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive cautiously and reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Not use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Use low beam headlights to better illuminate the road and objects.
questions.explanation: Fog can greatly reduce your ability to see other vehicles, pedestrians, and traffic signals. When driving in fog, drive cautiously and at reduced speeds. Do not use high beam headlights. Low beams better illuminate the road and objects ahead in foggy conditions.

questions.question: You should allow extra space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead of you when:
questions.answerA: Your car is cold.
questions.answerB: There are no vehicles behind you.
questions.answerC: You are following a motorcycle.
questions.answerD: You are listening to the radio.
questions.explanation: You should allow for a lengthened following distance in front of your vehicle when following a motorcycle. The additional space is needed to ensure that you do not hit the motorcycle rider if they fall off.

questions.question: As your speed increases, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Turn on your headlights.
questions.answerB: Look well ahead of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Change lanes frequently.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's stopping distance increases as your speed increases. When driving at high speeds, it is important to look well ahead of your vehicle to allow yourself space to safely react to hazardous situations.

questions.question: Water on the road can cause a vehicle to hydroplane. Your car may hydroplane at speeds as low as:
questions.answerA: 45 miles per hour.
questions.answerB: 35 miles per hour.
questions.answerC: 40 miles per hour.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when there is standing water on a roadway. At speeds up to 35 mph, most tires will channel water away from the tire. As your speed increases past 35 mph, tires cannot channel the water as well and your tires may start to lose contact with the road and ride over the water like a set of water skis.

questions.question: Highway pavement will be particularly treacherous and most slippery:
questions.answerA: If it has been raining several hours.
questions.answerB: If it has just begun to rain.
questions.answerC: If it has been raining for one to two hours.
questions.explanation: Pavement is particularly treacherous when it first begins to rain. Accumulations of dirt and oil mix with the rainwater, creating a greasy film on the roadway.

questions.question: A slow-moving vehicle emblem is:
questions.answerA: A rectangular red sign.
questions.answerB: A circular green sign.
questions.answerC: A diamond-shaped yellow sign.
questions.explanation: The slow-moving vehicle symbol is a reflective orange triangle. Expect vehicles using this emblem to be driving at speeds of 25 mph or slower.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: Roundabout ahead.
questions.answerC: No U-turns.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. This sign tells drivers that it is prohibited to make a U-turn.

questions.question: You come to an intersection with a flashing red light. You must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and drive carefully through the  intersection.
questions.answerB: Turn either right or left, since the road is blocked ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop at the intersection and wait for a flashing green light.
questions.answerD: Stop at the intersection, then proceed as traffic allows.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must come to a full stop, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: How can you help prevent rear-end collisions?
questions.answerA: Avoid sudden stops.
questions.answerB: Before stopping, check your mirrors and blind spots for traffic.
questions.answerC: Release the gas pedal and let your vehicle slow before applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Stopping suddenly can make it difficult for drivers behind you to avoid a rear-end collision. When stopping, release the accelerator to allow your vehicle to slow. Press the brake pedal by applying steady pressure, activating your brake lights and causing the vehicle to stop smoothly.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about large trucks?
questions.answerA: They take longer to stop than passenger vehicles.
questions.answerB: They all have air brakes that allow them to stop quickly.
questions.answerC: They are more maneuverable than passenger vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large trucks take longer to stop than other vehicles traveling at the same speed. The average passenger vehicle traveling at 55 mph can stop within 400 feet. However, a large truck traveling at the same speed can take almost 800 feet to stop.

questions.question: At a railroad crossing, you must:
questions.answerA: Watch for vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings (school buses, trucks carrying hazardous materials, etc.).
questions.answerB: Watch for multiple trains.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. Be aware of vehicles that must stop at all railroad crossings, such as school buses and trucks carrying hazardous materials.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers:
questions.answerA: That the right lane ends and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: That the road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: About upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane on a multilane roadway ends ahead. Traffic in the right lane must merge left.

questions.question: Two solid white lines painted across a traffic lane show the boundaries of a crosswalk. As a driver, you should know that:
questions.answerA: Motor vehicles have the right-of-way over pedestrians in crosswalks.
questions.answerB: When pedestrians are in crosswalks, they should be given the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: No one has the right-of-way in a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Pedestrians are responsible to stay out of the way of all traffic.
questions.explanation: Crosswalk lines show pedestrians where to safely cross a road or street. Crosswalks may be marked by horizontal lines, vertical lines, or a combination of the two. You must always stop for pedestrians who are in a crosswalk.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers that:
questions.answerA: The right lane is ending and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: The road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: There are upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that the number of lanes is reduced ahead and that traffic should merge left.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: Slow down and prepare to stop if cars are approaching you.
questions.answerB: Come to a full stop and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Proceed carefully through the intersection, not always stopping.
questions.answerD: Stop only for traffic on an intersecting road.
questions.explanation: A stop sign means that you must come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in or heading toward the intersection. Go again when it is safe.

questions.question: If the traffic light is red and you want to turn right, you can turn:
questions.answerA: When the cross traffic has cleared.
questions.answerB: After you stop.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign prohibits it, you may turn right at a red light after coming to a complete stop. When turning on red, you must yield to other traffic, pedestrians, and bicyclists before proceeding.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks only.
questions.answerB: Trucks are entering the highway.
questions.answerC: Upcoming hill.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that drivers are approaching a steep hill and should prepare to adjust their speeds to continue to drive safely.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Side road.
questions.answerB: Low clearance.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers to be aware of potential traffic entering from an upcoming side road.

questions.question: A leaking exhaust system can:
questions.answerA: Cause excessive oil use.
questions.answerB: Require your vehicle to have a tune-up sooner than normal.
questions.answerC: Make you drowsy while driving.
questions.answerD: Set grass fires on country roads.
questions.explanation: The exhaust system helps remove toxic gases, reduce the noise, and cool the hot gases coming from a running engine. Fumes from a leaky exhaust system can cause death in a very short time. They can also make you drowsy while driving.

questions.question: To avoid traction loss on wet roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Make abrupt turns.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes firmly.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, lower your speed in response to wet roads and keep your tires in good condition. If you detect a loss of control, take your foot off the gas, do not apply the brakes, maintain the direction of the vehicle, and allow the vehicle to slow to a manageable speed.

questions.question: This white sign means:
questions.answerA: The railroad crossing is controlled. Continue at your regular speed.
questions.answerB: Look, listen, and prepare to stop at the crossing if necessary.
questions.answerC: Stop at the railroad tracks and wait for a signal before crossing.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Let any trains pass before you proceed.

questions.question: You must not drive your vehicle at a speed greater than:
questions.answerA: The maximum speed limit.
questions.answerB: A speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent.
questions.answerC: A speed that is safe for existing conditions.
questions.explanation: You must not drive at a speed that is faster than is reasonable and prudent. You must drive at a speed that is appropriate for the area where you are driving, the type and condition of surrounding traffic, the presence of pedestrians, the weather, the quality of the road, and light conditions. You must drive within legal speed limits.

questions.question: Before stopping your vehicle at a traffic signal or sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Press down hard on the accelerator.
questions.answerB: Check your mirrors for surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Set the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When stopping your vehicle on the roadway, first check your mirrors for traffic. Be aware of surrounding drivers as you release the accelerator and allow your vehicle to slow. Move your foot to the brake pedal and press with steady pressure for a smooth stop.

questions.question: Drivers turning left must yield to:
questions.answerA: Oncoming vehicles traveling straight or turning right.
questions.answerB: Passing cars.
questions.answerC: No one in particular.
questions.explanation: Drivers making a left turn must yield to all vehicles approaching from the opposite direction. This includes bicycles and motorcycles.

questions.question: Allow a larger space cushion than usual when stopping:
questions.answerA: On an incline.
questions.answerB: At an intersection.
questions.answerC: At a stop sign.
questions.explanation: You should allow more space in front of your vehicle than usual when you are stopped on an uphill slope. If the vehicle in front of you rolls backward toward your vehicle when traffic begins to move again, it is less likely that there will be a collision.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing red light. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Slow down and drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop, check the traffic, and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to other traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when it safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Change in direction or narrowing of roadway.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: This sign warns a driver of a change in direction or a narrowing of the road. A driver may find several of these signs on the outside of a sharp curve or on approaches to a narrow bridge.

questions.question: When preparing to make a left turn from a two-way street, you should drive:
questions.answerA: Near the right-hand side of the road.
questions.answerB: Near the centerline.
questions.answerC: On the left of the centerline.
questions.explanation: When you are turning left from a two-way street, begin in the lane closest to the centerline and start your turn just before the front of your car reaches the center of the intersection. Do not cut the corner. Steering hand-over-hand, turn into the first available legal lane.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerA: 0.05 percent.
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: You should sound a sharp blast of your horn when:
questions.answerA: The driver ahead of you is driving under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: You exit an alley and cannot see what is ahead.
questions.answerC: Another vehicle is in danger of hitting you.
questions.answerD: You want to pass another vehicle.
questions.explanation: In situations that present no immediate danger, a light tap of the horn is generally sufficient to get the attention of others. A sharp blast of the horn should be used in situations of actual danger, such as when another vehicle is in danger of hitting you. You should not use your horn to encourage someone to drive faster or get out of the way.

questions.question: To see objects in their blind spot when changing lanes, drivers should check:
questions.answerA: Only the left outside mirror.
questions.answerB: Over their left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Only the inside rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's blind spots are the areas that you cannot see in your mirrors. Look over the appropriate shoulder to check your blind spot when changing lanes.

questions.question: On a road which has no sidewalks, a pedestrian should walk on the:
questions.answerA: Side of the road which has the lightest traffic.
questions.answerB: Same side of the road on which traffic is moving.
questions.answerC: Side of the road facing oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Side of the road which has the heaviest traffic.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians should walk on the side of the road facing the traffic in the lane nearest them.

questions.question: If you reach an intersection where you wish to turn but you are not in the proper lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly cut across traffic to make your turn.
questions.answerB: Turn on your blinker and make the turn from your current lane.
questions.answerC: Drive to the next intersection and make your turn then.
questions.answerD: Safely change lanes then put your vehicle in reverse to go back to the intersection.
questions.explanation: Never make last-minute turns. If you reach an intersection where you wish to turn but you are not in the proper lane to make the turn, drive to the next intersection and then make the turn from the proper lane.

questions.question: If another driver cuts you off in traffic, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull next to the driver and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Let it go.
questions.answerC: Flash your high beams at the driver.
questions.answerD: Get back at the other driver by cutting them off.
questions.explanation: To avoid the dangers of road rage, you should never take it personally if another driver cuts you off in traffic. Just let it go and continue driving safely.

questions.question: What can you do to reduce road rage?
questions.answerA: Always signal your intention when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerC: Use your horn frequently.
questions.explanation: To do your part to prevent road rage, you should follow laws, signs, signals, and pavement markings. Always signal your intention when changing lanes.

questions.question: When turning or changing lanes, you must:
questions.answerA: Always signal your intentions, even when no visible traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Signal only if there is visible traffic.
questions.answerC: Signal only when driving at night.
questions.answerD: Signal only when driving in heavy traffic at night.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions when changing lanes, turning, or pulling away from a curb. Do not allow yourself to become lazy and form the bad habit of not following this law.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Drivers making left turns must yield to oncoming traffic that is traveling straight. Drivers must always yield to pedestrians.

questions.question: Distracted driving may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Eating, drinking, or smoking.
questions.answerB: Talking or texting on a cellular phone.
questions.answerC: Changing a radio station or CD.
questions.explanation: It is estimated that drivers make 200 decisions for every mile traveled, making it vital that drivers focus their full attention on the task of driving. Performing any additional task can create a dangerous distraction.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Divided highway begins.
questions.answerB: A steep grade is ahead.
questions.answerC: The overpass ahead has a low clearance.
questions.answerD: Two lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions are about to merge.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. Do not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height indicated (in this case, 13 feet, 6 inches).

questions.question: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Immediately enter the far-right traffic lane on the interstate and speed up to match the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder of the main road to get up to the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Speed up and enter the interstate only after you have identified a gap in traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering the interstate on a short entrance ramp where there is no acceleration lane, speed up only after you have identified a gap in traffic. In general, you should be stopped while waiting for a gap to appear.

questions.question: What should you do when an emergency vehicle is approaching while displaying flashing red or blue lights?
questions.answerA: See if you can reach your destination before the emergency vehicle catches up to you.
questions.answerB: Continue driving but try to stay out of its way.
questions.answerC: Pull over to the side of the road and come to a complete stop.
questions.answerD: Stop in the middle of an intersection.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to all emergency vehicles using a siren, air horn, and/or flashing red, blue, or white lights. Where possible, you must pull over to the right edge of the road. If you are in an intersection, drive through the intersection before you pull over.

questions.question: You are driving in the left lane and want to move into the right lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over your left shoulder for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over your right shoulder for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over both shoulders for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Check your mirrors, signal, and change lanes.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, you should check your vehicle's blind spots by looking over your shoulder in the direction that you want to move. Always check your mirrors and turn on your directional signal before beginning a lane change.

questions.question: Taking drugs along with alcohol:
questions.answerA: Increases the risk of causing a crash.
questions.answerB: Is no more dangerous than consuming alcohol by itself.
questions.answerC: Lessens the effect of alcohol on your ability to drive.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your general driving ability.
questions.explanation: Drugs (including illegal, prescription, and over-the-counter medications) can affect your brain function and impair your ability to drive safely. Combining alcohol with other drugs will increase the risk of a crash.

questions.question: A sign with this shape means:
questions.answerA: No passing zone.
questions.answerB: Right turn permitted on red.
questions.answerC: Yield right-of-way.
questions.explanation: A pennant-shaped sign marks the beginning of a no passing zone.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Side road.
questions.answerB: Keep to the side indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerC: You may drive in the left lane.
questions.explanation: This is a "Keep right" sign. It indicates that a traffic island, median, or barrier is ahead and that drivers must keep to the right of it.

questions.question: A “No standing” sign at a certain location means:
questions.answerA: You may never stop your vehicle there.
questions.answerB: You may park there if the driver remains in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: You may stop temporarily only to pickup or discharge passengers.
questions.answerD: You may stop to load or unload merchandise.
questions.explanation: A "No standing" sign means that you may only make a temporary stop to load or discharge passengers.

questions.question: If a crossing guard is directing traffic in a school zone, you must:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions given by the crossing guard.
questions.answerB: Copy what surrounding traffic is doing, despite the crossing guard's instructions.
questions.answerC: Assume the guard is not supposed to be directing traffic.
questions.answerD: Follow rules that would be in place if no children were present.
questions.explanation: Be prepared to reduce your speed and use caution when directed to do so by a sign, crossing guard, or law enforcement officer. Always drive with extra caution in a school zone.

questions.question: When taking any medicine, you should:
questions.answerA: Consult your doctor about the effects before driving.
questions.answerB: Have someone follow you home.
questions.answerC: Keep your window open and drive more slowly.
questions.explanation: Legal medications, both prescription and over-the-counter, can potentially impair your ability to drive. Always consult with your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions about how a particular drug or drug combination will affect your ability to drive. You should particularly make a point of talking with your doctor if they give you a prescription for a tranquilizer or sedative.

questions.question: A diamond-shaped sign is a:
questions.answerA: Road hazard sign.
questions.answerB: Interstate route sign.
questions.answerC: School crossing sign.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are normally diamond-shaped and yellow, although orange warning signs are used in work areas. Such signs warn that you are approaching a hazardous location or an area where special rules apply.

questions.question: Which of the following are used on some highways to direct drivers into the proper lanes for turning?
questions.answerA: Flashing red lights
questions.answerB: Flashing yellow lights
questions.answerC: White lines on the side of the road
questions.answerD: White arrows in the middle of the lanes
questions.explanation: Arrows may be used to indicate which lanes should be used for specific purposes, such as driving straight or making a turn.

questions.question: The “No zone” is:
questions.answerA: A term used to describe blind spots around a truck or bus.
questions.answerB: A special speed zone.
questions.answerC: A roadway with restrictions on vehicle stereo volume.
questions.answerD: The television show that replaced The Twilight Zone.
questions.explanation: A truck or bus has blind spots on each side, in the rear, and in the front. An automobile cannot be seen in these blind spots. These blind spots are referred to as the “No zone.”

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.answerB: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop, if necessary.
questions.explanation: The stop sign is the only eight-sided sign you will see on any roadway. When you encounter a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop. You may not proceed until the way is clear for you to completely and safely pass through the intersection.

questions.question: You notice a vehicle defect which may affect the safe operation of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Correct the defect as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Correct the defect when you can afford it.
questions.answerC: Drive the vehicle at slower speeds.
questions.explanation: Any defect that may affect the safe operation of a vehicle should be corrected as soon as possible. Defects should be corrected before the vehicle is driven.

questions.question: An arrow painted on the pavement means:
questions.answerA: Drivers in the proper lane may make the movement indicated by the arrow, if they choose to do so.
questions.answerB: Drivers in the proper lane must make the movement indicated by the arrow, but only if traffic lights are not working.
questions.answerC: Drivers in the proper lane must always come to a complete stop before making the movement indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Drivers in the proper lane must make the movement indicated by the arrow while following directions indicated by traffic signals.
questions.explanation: An arrow painted on the pavement within a traffic lane indicates that drivers in the lane must make the movement indicated by the arrow. Drivers should follow directions given by any traffic signs or signals before proceeding in the direction indicated by the arrow.

questions.question: Having a driver license is a:
questions.answerA: Requirement.
questions.answerB: Privilege.
questions.answerC: Right.
questions.explanation: It is important to remember that driving is a privilege and that all drivers play a role in ensuring that everyone remains safe on the roadways. If you prove to be abusive of that privilege, the privilege may be revoked.

questions.question: When driving in fog, rain, or snow, use:
questions.answerA: Low beams.
questions.answerB: High beams.
questions.answerC: Fog lights only.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used in fog, rain, and snow. The light from high beams will reflect back to the driver under these weather conditions, causing a glare that will make it difficult to see ahead.

questions.question: You want to park uphill on a two-way road and there is no curb. Which direction do you turn your front wheels?
questions.answerA: Straight ahead
questions.answerB: Right, toward the side of the road
questions.answerC: Left, toward the center of the road
questions.explanation: When parking either uphill or downhill on a road that has no curb, you should turn your wheels so that the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail.

questions.question: When you park uphill on a street with a curb:
questions.answerA: Keep the front wheel straight and set the parking brake.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerD: Turn the back wheels into the curb.
questions.explanation: When parking on an incline where there is a curb, you should turn your wheels sharply to the left, away from the curb. This way, if your brakes fail, your vehicle will not roll into traffic.

questions.question: You must show proof of insurance to law enforcement:
questions.answerA: Only if you are involved in a collision.
questions.answerB: If you are involved in a collision or stopped for a citation.
questions.answerC: Only if you are stopped and cited.
questions.explanation: You must have evidence of financial responsibility, such as proof of insurance, with you whenever you drive. You must always show proof of insurance and your license to an officer upon request after a traffic stop or collision.

questions.question: When approaching a flashing yellow light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Increase their speed.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Turn on their headlights.
questions.answerD: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light warns of a hazard. Slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: After stopping for a school bus that is unloading children:
questions.answerA: Do not proceed until the children wave to you.
questions.answerB: Watch for children walking along the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Accelerate quickly.
questions.explanation: After stopping for a school bus that has its stop arm extended and its lights flashing, watch for children walking along the side of the road. You should always drive with caution when driving near children.

questions.question: On the freeway, you see a "Merging traffic“ sign. You should:
questions.answerA: Honk at incoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Always remain at your present speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up to avoid congesting traffic.
questions.answerD: Move to another lane, if safe, to let traffic enter.
questions.explanation: When on a roadway with two or more lanes, you should make room for entering vehicles. If there is no one driving next to you, move over one lane.

questions.question: A driver can legally pass on the right side of another vehicle:
questions.answerA: If the vehicle is waiting to turn left and there is an available passing lane.
questions.answerB: Even if it means driving off the pavement.
questions.answerC: On a narrow bridge.
questions.explanation: If there is an available passing lane, you may pass on the right of a vehicle or bicycle that is turning left or waiting to turn left. It is also legal to pass on the right when driving on a multilane road with two or more lanes traveling in the same direction. You may never drive off the pavement or main-traveled portion of the road to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: A steady yellow light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Go.
questions.answerB: Yield to other cars.
questions.answerC: Slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light indicates that a steady red light will soon appear. If you are driving toward an intersection and a yellow light appears, slow down and prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection or cannot stop safely before entering the intersection, continue through carefully.

questions.question: If it is necessary to make an emergency stop while driving on an interstate, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn at passing cars to get their attention.
questions.answerB: Get out of your vehicle and flag down the first vehicle that passes.
questions.answerC: Pull off the road, turn on your emergency flashers, and stay in your vehicle, if you can.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the shoulder of the interstate or highway, turn on your emergency flashers to warn other drivers and stay inside your vehicle, if you can. The extremely high speed of traffic makes standing or walking along an interstate highway very dangerous.

questions.question: When dealing with pedestrians, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Make sure the pedestrian is aware of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Always yield the right-of-way, even if the pedestrian is in the wrong.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way only when the pedestrian is legally entitled to it.
questions.answerD: Slow down and sound their horn near a crosswalk.
questions.explanation: You must do everything you can to prevent striking a pedestrian or another vehicle, regardless of the circumstances. It is the driver’s basic responsibility to be alert to pedestrians and to yield the right-of-way to all pedestrians, even if the pedestrian is crossing the street where they should not be.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers about:
questions.answerA: Upcoming intersections.
questions.answerB: Road construction.
questions.answerC: An upcoming curve in the road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead curves to the right.

questions.question: What is the first thing you should adjust, if needed, when you get into a car to drive?
questions.answerA: Your seat belt
questions.answerB: The steering wheel
questions.answerC: Your rearview mirror
questions.explanation: When preparing to drive, you should first adjust your seat to ensure that you are in a comfortable position and can see the road clearly. Adjust your mirrors and steering wheel to be effective when your seat is fully adjusted.

questions.question: When driving, how often should you check your rearview mirror for traffic behind you?
questions.answerA: Every two to four seconds
questions.answerB: Every four to six seconds
questions.answerC: Every six to eight seconds
questions.explanation: Every six to eight seconds, you should look at your rearview mirror to check on the traffic behind you.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Keep right.
questions.answerB: Keep left.
questions.answerC: Pass with caution.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. The road splits into two one-way roadways separated by a median or divider. You must keep to the right.

questions.question: Stopping distances and severity of crashes:
questions.answerA: Decrease as vehicle speed increases.
questions.answerB: Are not affected by vehicle speed.
questions.answerC: Increase as vehicle speed increases.
questions.explanation: Stopping distances are longer and crashes are more severe when traffic travels at higher speeds.

questions.question: To know where traffic is behind you:
questions.answerA: Frequently check your rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Turn and look out your back window.
questions.answerC: Keep other vehicles out of your blind spots.
questions.explanation: Drivers should check their rearview mirrors often to stay aware of the position of traffic behind them.

questions.question: Excessive speed:
questions.answerA: Does not increase the chance of a crash.
questions.answerB: Increases your ability to react to a hazard.
questions.answerC: Often leads to high-risk decision-making.
questions.explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.

questions.question: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or using a guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and be prepared to stop.
questions.answerB: Take the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Proceed normally.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle on a road with two lanes traveling in opposite directions, you should:
questions.answerA: Return to the driving lane when there's enough room between you and the vehicle you passed.
questions.answerB: Remain in the left lane if you intend to turn left.
questions.answerC: Return to the right side of the roadway immediately.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on a two-lane roadway, you must return to the right side of the roadway when there is enough room between you and the vehicle you have passed.

questions.question: Backing your vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Always dangerous.
questions.answerB: Dangerous if you have a helper.
questions.answerC: Only dangerous in large vehicles.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is hard to see behind your vehicle. Use extra caution when backing up.

questions.question: If you are driving on a one-way street and an emergency vehicle using its flashing lights approaches your vehicle, you must:
questions.answerA: Drive with your flashers turned on.
questions.answerB: Drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.
questions.answerC: Speed up and take the nearest exit.
questions.answerD: Slow down until the vehicle passes you.
questions.explanation: If an emergency vehicle using its lights or siren approaches while you are driving on a one-way street, you must drive toward the nearest roadside and stop.

questions.question: When exiting a highway, you should slow down:
questions.answerA: On the main road, just before the exit lane.
questions.answerB: Once you see a toll booth.
questions.answerC: Once you have moved into the exit lane.
questions.answerD: When you first see the exit sign.
questions.explanation: When exiting a highway, you should get into the exit lane well in advance. Do not begin to slow down until after you have moved into the exit lane.

questions.question: Collisions are more likely to happen when:
questions.answerA: All vehicles are traveling at about the same speed.
questions.answerB: One lane of traffic is traveling faster than the other lanes.
questions.answerC: One vehicle is traveling faster or slower than the flow of traffic.
questions.explanation: Collisions are more likely to happen when one driver moves faster or slower than the other vehicles on the road. Driving faster than other traffic increases your chance of being involved in a collision. Driving more slowly than other traffic is also dangerous because it can increase the risk of a rear-end collision with your vehicle or cause other drivers to swerve to avoid hitting you.

questions.question: Just like alcohol and other drugs, drowsiness can:
questions.answerA: Help you to be a better driver.
questions.answerB: Make you feel better.
questions.answerC: Impair your judgment.
questions.explanation: Not getting enough sleep is a cause of poor driving behavior. Just like drugs and alcohol, sleepiness slows reaction time, decreases awareness, and impairs judgment.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn to the right.
questions.answerB: Double curve.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead winds with a series of turns or curves.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Trucks under 18,000 pounds are allowed.
questions.answerB: Hill ahead.
questions.answerC: Truck stop ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign indicates that there is a steep hill ahead. Slow down and be ready to shift to a lower gear to control your speed and protect your brakes from damage.

questions.question: What does an orange-colored sign indicate?
questions.answerA: The start of a no passing zone.
questions.answerB: A railroad crossing is ahead.
questions.answerC: A school zone is ahead.
questions.explanation: Construction, maintenance, and emergency operations signs are generally orange with black symbols.

questions.question: When stopped at a red traffic light with a green arrow, you may proceed in the direction of the arrow if you:
questions.answerA: First come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: Wait until the light changes.
questions.answerC: Are in the proper lane and the intersection is clear.
questions.explanation: You may proceed in the direction that a green arrow signal is pointing if you are in the proper lane, regardless of any other signals that are displayed. Before turning, you must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicles already within the intersection.

questions.question: A fully loaded tractor-trailer traveling at 55 mph could take up to ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.answerA: 50 feet
questions.answerB: 125 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: Tractor-trailers take longer distances to stop than smaller cars traveling at the same speed. A fully loaded tractor-trailer may take almost 400 feet to come to a complete stop when driving at 55 mph.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you can check your blind spots by:
questions.answerA: Using the inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Using the outside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Using both inside and outside rearview mirrors.
questions.answerD: Turning your head and looking over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: You should turn your head to check your blind spots before every lane change.

questions.question: Drinking coffee after drinking alcohol:
questions.answerA: Decreases blood alcohol concentration.
questions.answerB: Cancels the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Has no effect on blood alcohol concentration.
questions.explanation: Drinking coffee will not reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC). While it may help you to stay awake, it cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: When parking next to a curb, you should use your turn signals:
questions.answerA: Only when pulling away from the curb.
questions.answerB: When pulling next to, but not away from, the curb.
questions.answerC: When pulling next to or away from the curb.
questions.explanation: Drivers should signal when pulling next to a curb or away from a curb.

questions.question: The most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of being injured or killed in a traffic crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear your seat belt.
questions.answerB: Limit your driving to weekdays.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane on multilane highways.
questions.answerD: Limit your driving to hours between 3:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m.
questions.explanation: Wearing your seat belt is the single most effective thing you can do to reduce your risk of death or injury while driving.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down.
questions.answerB: Look for a train.
questions.answerC: Be ready to stop.
questions.explanation: When you see any signs indicating a nearby railroad crossing, you should slow down, look for a train, and be ready to stop. If the red warning lights are flashing or the gate is down, you must stop 15 to 50 feet before the railroad tracks. Do not try to go around the gate.

questions.question: Which of the following blocks the smooth flow of traffic?
questions.answerA: Slowing down to look at collision scene.
questions.answerB: Avoiding unnecessary lane changes.
questions.answerC: Using public transportation instead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Rubbernecking (the practice of slowing down to look at collisions or other out-of-the-ordinary things) contributes to traffic congestion and should be avoided.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: Stop sign ahead.
questions.answerC: Divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that turns in the direction of the arrow (in this case, to the right) are prohibited.

questions.question: Alcohol in any concentration is:
questions.answerA: A stimulant.
questions.answerB: A depressant.
questions.answerC: Neither of the above.
questions.explanation: Alcohol, in any concentration, is a depressant. It slows all nerve impulses and bodily functions, resulting in a lessening of inhibitions and negatively affecting a consumer's ability to concentrate and stay alert.

questions.question: This sign means:
