questions.answerA: Trucks entering.
questions.answerB: Truck exit only.
questions.answerC: Steep downgrade ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that a steep downgrade is ahead on the road. Drivers should check their brakes.

questions.question: If an officer is directing traffic at a working traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions indicated by the traffic light.
questions.answerB: Follow the directions given by the officer.
questions.answerC: Honk at the officer.
questions.answerD: Check to see what the cars next to them are doing.
questions.explanation: Traffic signals are placed at intersections to keep traffic moving and to help prevent crashes. Drivers, pedestrians, and cyclists must obey these signals, except in instances when an officer is directing traffic.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed limit in residential and business areas where there are no posted speed limits?
questions.answerA: 15 mph
questions.answerB: 25 mph
questions.answerC: 35 mph
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit on residential and business streets is 25 miles per hour.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about roadwork zones?
questions.answerA: Fines are the same for violations committed in work zones as they are under normal traffic conditions.
questions.answerB: You must "Slow for the Cone Zone."
questions.answerC: Slow down only if you think workers are present.
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed and be prepared to slow down or stop for highway equipment. Driving carefully through work zones improves safety for drivers, pedestrians, bicyclists, and road workers.

questions.question: A bicyclist who doesn’t obey traffic laws:
questions.answerA: Is in the right because bicyclists don’t have to obey traffic laws.
questions.answerB: Can be ticketed.
questions.answerC: Will always receive a warning from law enforcement.
questions.explanation: All bicyclists have the same rights, duties, and responsibilities as drivers of motor vehicles. Motorists and bicyclists who do not obey traffic laws can be ticketed.

questions.question: When approaching a person who is crossing the street while using a white cane or guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the person is well away from your path of travel.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn as you proceed past them.
questions.answerC: Carefully drive around them.
questions.explanation: When approaching a pedestrian who is using a white cane or guide dog while crossing the street, you must stop until the person is well away from your path of travel. Always yield the right-of-way to blind pedestrians.

questions.question: When parking your vehicle downhill on a two-way street:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels to the right.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels to the left.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels pointed straight ahead.
questions.explanation: When you park on a downward-facing slope, turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road. This way, if your vehicle starts to roll downhill, it will roll away from traffic.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Drive with caution and be ready to slow down.
questions.answerB: Do not drive in this lane.
questions.answerC: You must come to a complete stop and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Slow down, be prepared to stop, and, if necessary, yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This type of triangular sign means drivers must yield. You must slow down as you come to an intersection marked with this sign and be prepared to stop. Let any other vehicles, bicyclists, or pedestrians pass safely before you proceed.

questions.question: When approaching an uncontrolled intersection, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Maintain their speed and proceed.
questions.answerB: Stop at the intersection, check in all directions, and proceed.
questions.answerC: Yield to all other drivers.
questions.explanation: At an intersection where there is no stop sign or traffic signal, you should yield to a vehicle approaching the intersection from the right. However, always be prepared to yield to avoid a crash. Do this by taking your foot off the accelerator, covering the brake, and looking left, right, and left again.

questions.question: When sharing the road with a truck, it is important to remember that trucks generally:
questions.answerA: Require longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerB: Require less time to pass on a downgrade than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerC: Require a smaller turning radius than smaller vehicles do.
questions.answerD: Require less time to pass on an incline than smaller vehicles do.
questions.explanation: Because of their size, trucks need longer distances to stop than smaller vehicles do.

questions.question: When you see this sign, it means:
questions.answerA: There is an object on the roadway.
questions.answerB: Traffic is coming from the right.
questions.answerC: The road is curving sharply to the left.
questions.answerD: There is a merge point ahead.
questions.explanation: Chevron signs like this indicate that the road curves sharply in the direction indicated by the chevron (in this case, to the left). There may be several chevron signs placed throughout a curve.

questions.question: When the road is marked with a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line, with the broken line next to your lane, you may pass:
questions.answerA: Only in an emergency.
questions.answerB: If you are on an expressway.
questions.answerC: If traffic is clear.
questions.explanation: When there is a solid yellow line and a broken yellow line in the center of the road and the broken line is next to your lane, you may cross the lines to pass if there is no oncoming traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn ahead, slow down.
questions.answerB: Work crew ahead.
questions.answerC: Side road.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that there is an upcoming sharp turn and that they should lower their speed accordingly.

questions.question: Distracted driving is:
questions.answerA: Very uncommon.
questions.answerB: Extremely risky behavior.
questions.answerC: Nothing to be concerned about.
questions.answerD: No less safe than driving under any other conditions.
questions.explanation: Distracted driving is extremely risky behavior that puts not only you and your passengers in danger, but also endangers pedestrians, bicyclists, and other motorists sharing the road. Focused attention on driving helps to prevent crashes.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Bicycle crossing.
questions.answerB: Stop only if other cars are approaching.
questions.answerC: Bicycle store.
questions.explanation: This sign (with the arrow below) indicates the location of a bicycle crossing/path. Drive with caution around this sign because bicycles likely regularly cross or ride beside traffic in the area.

questions.question: If worried, nervous, angry, or crying, a driver:
questions.answerA: Will drive no differently than they would if they were thinking more clearly.
questions.answerB: Can drive faster because they are more in touch with their senses.
questions.answerC: Should take the time to focus on driving before starting the engine.
questions.answerD: Should call a friend to vent while driving.
questions.explanation: You may not be able to drive well if you are worried, excited, crying, angry, or depressed. Emotions can distract you from your driving because your mind is focused on something else. Take time to calm down and get focused before driving.

questions.question: When a car with bright headlights drives toward you at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the other driver passes.
questions.answerB: Look below their headlights.
questions.answerC: Glance toward the right edge of your lane.
questions.explanation: To avoid being blinded when driving at night, do not look directly at the headlights of oncoming cars. Instead, look toward the right edge of the road until the oncoming driver has passed.

questions.question: Changing from one lane to another is best done:
questions.answerA: Quickly and often.
questions.answerB: When a car is in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Gradually and carefully.
questions.explanation: You should always change lanes gradually and carefully. Only change lanes when necessary. Every lane change increases the possibility of a traffic accident.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow arrow indicates that left turns are allowed in the direction of the arrow. However, the oncoming traffic has a green light and you must yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: The blind spot behind a large truck can extend for up to:
questions.answerA: 80 feet.
questions.answerB: 100 feet.
questions.answerC: 150 feet.
questions.explanation: The blind spot behind a large truck can extend for up to 200 feet behind the truck's cab.

questions.question: To avoid collisions with vehicles in your blind spots, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn your head to see if your blind spot is clear before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Adjust your rearview mirrors every few minutes.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn right before turning or changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Before turning or changing lanes, turn your head and glance over your shoulder in the direction of your move to see if your blind spot is clear. Never rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: You are approaching a railroad crossing that has no visible gates or flashing lights, but has a standard crossbuck. You should:
questions.answerA: Approach all tracks with extreme caution and cross only when you know that there is no train coming.
questions.answerB: Turn your radio down to hear if there may be an approaching train.
questions.answerC: Only continue once cleared to do so by a flagger, if applicable.
questions.explanation: You must approach all railroad crossings with extreme caution and cross only when you know that no train is coming from either direction. If there is a flagger at a crossing, you must obey all of their instructions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn left.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign means drivers cannot make a left turn. It is unsafe and unlawful to make a left turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: A solid yellow line next to a broken yellow line means that vehicles:
questions.answerA: Driving in both directions may pass.
questions.answerB: Next to the broken line may pass.
questions.answerC: Next to the solid line may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions. A broken yellow line next to your driving lane means that you may pass.

questions.question: Using a cell phone while operating a motor vehicle is considered a distraction because:
questions.answerA: It causes the driver to be concerned about the cost of the call.
questions.answerB: It occupies the driver's hands, eyes, and mind.
questions.answerC: It is an activity that draws the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone while driving is dangerous because it occupies the user's eyes, hands, and mind. Even the most skilled drivers increase their risk of being involved in a crash by using a cell phone on the road.

questions.question: If bad weather makes it difficult for you to see clearly, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to get off the road quickly.
questions.answerB: Drive in the lane closest to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: When it is difficult to see due to darkness or poor weather, increase your following distance. This will give you more time to react to hazards that you may not see in advance.

questions.question: Stress can affect your driving by:
questions.answerA: Lowing your ability to focus on driving.
questions.answerB: Decreasing your chances of an accident.
questions.answerC: Causing you to fall asleep at the wheel.
questions.answerD: Making you more aware of others around you.
questions.explanation: Emotions can have a great effect on your driving ability. You may not be able to drive well if you are overly worried, excited, afraid, angry, or sad. Stress can lessen your concentration on the task of driving. It is better to wait to drive than to risk driving while you are emotionally unstable.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection controlled by a flashing yellow light, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop at the intersection.
questions.answerB: Maintain your normal speed.
questions.answerC: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow light indicates that you should be alert and proceed with caution. Slow down when approaching a flashing yellow traffic signal.

questions.question: It is against the law to park within ____ feet of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: It is against the law to park within 10 feet of a fire hydrant.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady green arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn in the direction of the arrow after yielding to traffic and pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerD: May drive straight through the intersection.
questions.explanation: A green arrow displayed on a traffic signal tells drivers that they may turn in the direction of the arrow. You must be in the proper lane for such a turn. Yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians already in the intersection.

questions.question: You are turning onto a two-lane road divided by a broken yellow line. You know immediately that:
questions.answerA: You are on a two-way road.
questions.answerB: You are on a one-way road.
questions.answerC: The road is under repair.
questions.answerD: You must stay to the left of the broken yellow lines.
questions.explanation: Yellow centerlines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Broken lines may be crossed to pass slower-moving traffic when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lane markings mean that:
questions.answerA: Neither lane may pass.
questions.answerB: Both lanes may pass.
questions.answerC: The lane to the right may pass.
questions.explanation: Yellow lane markings indicate a separation of lanes where traffic is traveling in opposite directions. When you see double solid yellow lane markings, passing is prohibited from both directions.

questions.question: The best way to avoid hydroplaning is to:
questions.answerA: Keep your tires properly maintained.
questions.answerB: Slow down when roads are wet or slushy.
questions.answerC: Watch out for standing water or puddles.
questions.explanation: When roads are wet, cars take a longer distance to stop and may skid on quick turns. Do not use cruise control when driving under wet or icy conditions. Reduce your speed and drive with caution.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop sign ahead.
questions.answerB: Lane closed ahead.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This warning sign indicates that a traffic signal is ahead and drivers should prepare to react to a yellow or red light.

questions.question: On a green arrow, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield to any vehicle, bicycle, or pedestrian in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield to pedestrians only in the intersection.
questions.answerC: Wait four seconds before proceeding.
questions.explanation: A green arrow means "go." You must turn in the direction the arrow is pointing after you yield to any vehicles, bicycles, or pedestrians who are still in the intersection.

questions.question: A broken yellow line beside a solid yellow line indicates that passing is:
questions.answerA: Permitted from the side next to the solid yellow line.
questions.answerB: Not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerC: Permitted from the side next to the broken yellow line.
questions.explanation: When the center of the road is marked by a solid yellow line beside a broken yellow line, passing is permitted from the side next to the broken line and prohibited from the side next to the solid line.

questions.question: If you become drowsy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to fight it.
questions.answerB: Take a break.
questions.answerC: Take some caffeine pills.
questions.explanation: If you start to feel tired while driving, drive to the first available rest stop or service area to take a break, nap, stretch, or change drivers. You should not rely on caffeine pills or energy drinks, as these are not a replacement for rest and may make your driving even more dangerous.

questions.question: A pedestrian starts to cross in front of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Flash your lights.
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Speed up and pass in front of the pedestrian.
questions.answerD: Stop and let the pedestrian cross.
questions.explanation: Slow down and be prepared to stop whenever you see pedestrians walking on or crossing the roadway. Be particularly careful where children are present. Always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian crossing in a crosswalk.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn left.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No U-turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: A solid yellow line on your side of the centerline means:
questions.answerA: Slow down.
questions.answerB: Pass with caution.
questions.answerC: Do not pass.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow line next to your lane means that passing is not permitted from your direction.

questions.question: To help avoid skidding on slippery surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift to a lower gear after starting down a steep hill.
questions.answerB: Speed up to enter curves and slow down to exit them.
questions.answerC: Slow down before entering curves and intersections.
questions.explanation: Slow down before you enter a curve because you do not know what may be ahead. Braking on a curve may cause you to skid.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn right.
questions.answerB: All traffic must go straight.
questions.answerC: A side road intersects ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This warning sign tells drivers to be alert to an intersecting side road ahead.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel at the speed indicated.
questions.answerB: The maximum legal speed on the roadway is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed.
questions.explanation: This is a speed limit sign. It indicates the maximum legal speed that you may drive on the road where it is posted. At times of rain, snow, ice, or other less-than-ideal conditions, you may have to drive more slowly than the posted limit.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about driving speed is true?
questions.answerA: As your speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases.
questions.answerB: As your speed increases, so should your following distance.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: As driving speeds increase, the chance of a fatality in the case of a collision increases. If you are going faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. The speed you drive affects your stopping distance, so you should increase your following distance as you increase your speed.

questions.question: The act of turning your head and checking your blind spot before changing lanes, driving away from a curb, or merging your vehicle into traffic is:
questions.answerA: A bad driving habit.
questions.answerB: A good driving habit.
questions.answerC: Unnecessary.
questions.answerD: Not necessary if you use the rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, it is important to check your blind spots. Do this by looking over your shoulder toward the next lane. Do not rely only on your mirrors.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Steep downgrade.
questions.answerB: Crossroad ahead.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming steep hill. They should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid brake damage or collision.

questions.question: Seat belts are required to be worn:
questions.answerA: Only by children younger than 16 years old.
questions.answerB: Only by the driver.
questions.answerC: By everyone in a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Wisconsin law requires that the driver and all passengers wear seat belts while in a moving vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: No passing zone.
questions.answerB: Winding road.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates a low ground railroad crossing. Where this sign is present, railroad tracks cross the road at a steep slope and the bottom of low vehicles may drag or get caught on the tracks.

questions.question: How far ahead of an intended turn should you activate your turn signal?
questions.answerA: 25 feet
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 75 feet
questions.explanation: You should signal 100 feet before you intend to turn. However, you should be careful if there are other streets, driveways, or entrances between your current location and the location of the turn. Wait to activate your turn signal until there are no other possible turns between you and your desired turning location.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn.
questions.answerB: Turn right at the intersection.
questions.answerC: Parking area ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the presence of a crossroad ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No left turn can be made here.
questions.answerB: A left turn can be made only after stopping.
questions.answerC: All traffic must turn right at the next intersection.
questions.explanation: Signs with a red circle and diagonal line over a black symbol indicate that the action represented by the symbol is prohibited. In this case, the sign indicates that left turns are prohibited.

questions.question: A person's ability to drive can be impaired by:
questions.answerA: Alcohol.
questions.answerB: Any medication.
questions.answerC: A lack of sleep.
questions.explanation: The ability to drive safely is dependent on the driver being in good physical condition. Driving can be impaired by alcohol, legal and illegal drugs, and being drowsy.

questions.question: If your vehicle starts to lose traction because of water on the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Drive at a constant speed to gain better traction.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes firmly to prevent your vehicle from sliding.
questions.answerC: Slow down gradually and not apply the brakes.
questions.explanation: When driving in heavy rain at speeds as low as 30 mph, your tires may lose all contact with the road and instead ride up on a layer of water above the surface of the road. This is called "hydroplaning." If your vehicle starts to hydroplane, slow down gradually and do not apply the brakes.

questions.question: If you stop along the road at night:
questions.answerA: Turn off all your lights.
questions.answerB: Use your parking lights only.
questions.answerC: Use your headlights only.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beams turned on.
questions.explanation: If you stop along the road at night, turn on your emergency flashers and leave your low beam headlights turned on. Be sure that other road users will be able to clearly see your vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not enter.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.explanation: This sign is posted on one-way streets and other roadways where a driver is not allowed to enter. A driver may see this sign if attempting to enter an expressway ramp in the wrong direction.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: A sudden change in weather calls for a change in driving.
questions.answerB: You should slow down when driving in rain and fog.
questions.answerC: Be particularly aware of vehicles coming up behind you in inclement weather.
questions.explanation: If the weather changes suddenly, you will need to adjust your driving to adapt. Always slow down when driving in rainy or foggy conditions. Be especially aware of vehicles behind you that may be going too fast for conditions.

questions.question: A work zone:
questions.answerA: May be moving or stationary.
questions.answerB: Is marked with black and white signs.
questions.answerC: Does not require a driver to slow down and pay extra attention.
questions.explanation: Work zones are often stationary, but they may also be present in the form of moving vehicles striping lines, mowing, or removing snow. Work zones are marked by orange signs with black lettering or symbols. Slow down and pay extra attention when approaching or driving through a work zone.

questions.question: If you parallel park facing downward on a hill:
questions.answerA: Turn your wheels sharply toward the side of the road.
questions.answerB: Turn your wheels away from the side of the road.
questions.answerC: Keep your wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking downhill, turn your front wheels toward the curb or edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road without a curb, turn your wheels toward the edge of the road. When parking uphill on a road with a curb, you must turn your front wheels away from the curb.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down.
questions.answerB: Drive more quickly.
questions.answerC: Drive the speed limit, with caution.
questions.answerD: Not drive more quickly than 20 mph.
questions.explanation: You should slow down at the first sign of rain, snow, or sleet, all of which can create slippery road conditions. When conditions on the road are less than ideal, safety may require that you drive more slowly than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with airbags:
questions.answerA: Seat belts should still be worn.
questions.answerB: Seat belts do not need to be worn.
questions.answerC: Seat belts should be worn behind the back.
questions.explanation: Airbags are important safety devices that provide protection in crashes. For best protection, a vehicle's lap and shoulder belts should be used in combination with airbags.

questions.question: If your car's suspension is bad, it can cause:
questions.answerA: Vehicle control problems.
questions.answerB: Squealing brakes.
questions.answerC: Slack in the steering.
questions.explanation: Your suspension helps you control your vehicle and provides a comfortable ride over varying road surfaces. If your vehicle bounces a lot after driving over a bump, or is generally hard to control, you may need new suspension parts.

questions.question: When you drive through an area where children are playing, you should expect them:
questions.answerA: To know when it is safe to cross the street.
questions.answerB: To stop at the curb before crossing the street.
questions.answerC: To run out in front of you without looking.
questions.answerD: Not to cross the street unless they are with an adult.
questions.explanation: You should always reduce your speed and use extra caution when children are in the vicinity. They may fail to understand the danger and may run out in front of you without looking.

questions.question: Adjust your rearview and side mirrors:
questions.answerA: Before you start driving.
questions.answerB: Whenever you need to use them.
questions.answerC: Before you get into the car.
questions.explanation: Your safety and the safety of other drivers and pedestrians depends a lot on what you do before driving. Before moving your vehicle, you should adjust your seat, adjust your mirrors, fasten your safety belt, and secure items in and on your vehicle. Do not wait until your vehicle is moving to adjust your mirrors.

questions.question: Consuming which of the following substances may impair your ability to drive safely and may result in an arrest for driving under the influence of intoxicants (DUII)?
questions.answerA: Beer, wine, and other liquor
questions.answerB: Controlled substances, such as illegal drugs or prescription medicines
questions.answerC: Inhalants, such as glue or paint
questions.explanation: A wide variety of intoxicants can impair your ability to drive. These include all types of alcoholic beverages, illegal drugs, inhalants, and many legal medications (both prescription and over-the-counter).

questions.question: “Highway hypnosis” is a driving condition that can result from:
questions.answerA: Staring at the roadway for long periods of time.
questions.answerB: Frequent rest stops.
questions.answerC: Too much sleep the night before your trip.
questions.explanation: "Highway hypnosis” happens when you stare straight ahead at the roadway for long periods of time and stop actively scanning ahead, behind, and around your vehicle. This can lead you to zone out, making you very likely to crash into traffic slowing or stopping ahead of you.

questions.question: Larger vehicles have:
questions.answerA: Larger blind spots.
questions.answerB: Smaller blind spots.
questions.answerC: No blind spots.
questions.answerD: The same blind spots as smaller vehicles.
questions.explanation: The larger the vehicle, the larger the blind spots. Large trucks and SUVs have spots close to their rears that cannot be seen in their side or rearview mirrors.

questions.question: Driving while being distracted by any activity:
questions.answerA: Is never dangerous.
questions.answerB: Usually causes the driver to react more slowly to hazards.
questions.answerC: Usually causes the driver to drive faster.
questions.answerD: Is only dangerous for young drivers.
questions.explanation: Distractions cause drivers to react more slowly to traffic and hazards on the roadway. Distracted driving is never safe.

questions.question: You may cross double yellow lines to pass another vehicle if the:
questions.answerA: Vehicle in front of you moves to the right to let you pass.
questions.answerB: Yellow line next to your side of the road is broken.
questions.answerC: Yellow line next to the opposite side of the road is broken.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow line in the center of the road indicates that traffic next to the broken yellow line may pass, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerB: U-turns are permitted.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: A regulatory sign displaying a red circle with a red slash through the middle indicates that a specific action is prohibited. U-turns are not permitted where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Excessive speed:
questions.answerA: Saves time so you can get to your destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Helps you maneuver around obstacles.
questions.answerC: Increases the likelihood of serious bodily injury and death.
questions.explanation: Excessive speed is one of the most common contributing factors to vehicle crashes. Excessive speed does not save time and often leads to high-risk decision-making.

questions.question: If you are turning onto a street with more than one lane traveling in your direction, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerB: Turn into the lane marked with an arrow.
questions.answerC: Turn into the middle lane.
questions.explanation: When turning onto a street with more than one lane moving in the direction that you are traveling, turn into the lane that is closest to your previous lane. Do not change lanes when turning.

questions.question: A flashing red traffic signal at an intersection has the same requirements as:
questions.answerA: A slow sign.
questions.answerB: A yield sign.
questions.answerC: A stop sign.
questions.explanation: When approaching a flashing red signal, you must stop and yield to all traffic that does not have to stop.

questions.question: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Grip the steering wheel firmly, slow down, and exit the traffic lane.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes rapidly.
questions.answerC: Brake hard and steer toward the right edge of the roadway.
questions.explanation: If you experience a sudden tire blowout, do not panic. Grasp the steering wheel firmly and take your foot off the accelerator to allow the vehicle to roll to a stop. Lightly apply the breaks when it is safe to do so. Do not move to the shoulder of the road until the car has slowed considerably.

questions.question: As the percentage of alcohol (BAC) in your blood increases, you become:
questions.answerA: More intoxicated.
questions.answerB: More sober.
questions.answerC: More coordinated.
questions.explanation: Blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is a measure of the percentage of alcohol in a person's blood. The higher the BAC, the more impaired a person is.

questions.question: If you have a probationary license or instructional permit, you can use your cell phone while driving:
questions.answerA: If you are just answering a call.
questions.answerB: As long as you don't text.
questions.answerC: When you are reporting an emergency.
questions.explanation: If you have a probationary license or instructional permit, using a cell phone while driving in Wisconsin is against the law. The only exception to this is if you must use your cell phone to report an emergency.

questions.question: Interstate driving requires drivers to:
questions.answerA: Have the ability to safely drive at increased speeds.
questions.answerB: Be constantly alert.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Safe use of the interstate demands drivers be constantly alert and capable of driving at high speeds.

questions.question: When you see this yellow sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop at the crosswalk.
questions.answerB: Stop at the crosswalk until a crossing guards signals for you to go.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop if children are in the crosswalk.
questions.explanation: A five-sided sign indicates that you are near a school. Be aware and stop if children are in the crosswalk.

questions.question: You should increase your following distance:
questions.answerA: At night.
questions.answerB: When it is raining.
questions.answerC: Both of the above
questions.explanation: A four-second following distance is recommended for ideal driving conditions. There are a number of circumstances when a lengthier following distance should be applied, including times when it is difficult to see because of darkness or bad weather.

questions.question: If you stop at a railroad crossing with more than one track:
questions.answerA: Wait to proceed until you have a clear view of all tracks.
questions.answerB: Stop on the first railroad track and watch for another train.
questions.answerC: Go through as soon as the train passes.
questions.answerD: Go through when one of the tracks is free.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing with more than one track, do not start moving as soon as a train passes. Wait until you have a clear view down all tracks before you start across. Even where there is only one track, do not start across immediately after a train passes; check again for another train that may be approaching.

questions.question: You may park or stop along the shoulder of the freeway:
questions.answerA: As long as you turn on your four-way (emergency) flashers.
questions.answerB: If no part of your vehicle is on the road.
questions.answerC: If you need to look at a map for directions.
questions.answerD: Only if you have an emergency.
questions.explanation: It is prohibited to park on the shoulder of a freeway, except in an emergency.

questions.question: A driver should be extra alert to motorcyclists, bicyclists, and pedestrians because:
questions.answerA: They’re difficult to see in traffic.
questions.answerB: They obey different traffic laws than larger motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: They always have the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: In many collisions with motorcycles, bicycles, and pedestrians, drivers reported that they were looking but still did not see the smaller vehicle or pedestrian. These can be more difficult to spot in traffic than passenger vehicles because they are smaller, may move faster, and have less noticeable lighting. To prevent collisions with these smaller and less protected road users, drivers should always be alert to the presence of motorcycles, bikes, and pedestrians.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam headlights. If the fog is so bad that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: Anything that requires you to ____ could cause you to crash.
questions.answerA: Take your eyes off the road
questions.answerB: Take your hands off the wheel
questions.answerC: Take your attention away from the task of driving
questions.explanation: Anything that causes you to take your attention away from driving, take your eyes off the road, and/or take your hands off the wheel is a distraction.

questions.question: Is it legal cross a double solid yellow centerline to pass?
questions.answerA: Yes.
questions.answerB: No.
questions.answerC: If there is no oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: If the vehicle ahead of you is driving under the speed limit.
questions.explanation: Two solid yellow lines down the center of a two-way road mean that neither lane of traffic may cross the lines, unless they are turning off of the roadway. A driver can cross double yellow lines when turning into or out of a driveway or entrance to a business. No passing is allowed over a solid yellow line.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is merging traffic entering from the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No parking.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Left turn signal.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that parking is not permitted.

questions.question: Driving under the influence of any medication which impairs your driving is permitted:
questions.answerA: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerB: If you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: If it is prescribed by a physician.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to drive under the influence of any substance that impairs your ability to drive safely. This includes alcohol, prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs.

questions.question: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for:
questions.answerA: The increased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerB: The decreased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerC: The decreased noise of larger vehicles.
questions.answerD: The increased speed of larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for the increased stopping distance required by the large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should remain in locations where they can be seen by the driver of the large vehicle and where their view of traffic is not blocked by the vehicle.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: School crossing.
questions.answerB: School zone.
questions.answerC: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign marks the presence of a crosswalk. Be alert to any pedestrians that may be crossing the roadway.

questions.question: You must yield to a pedestrian using a white cane or guide dog:
questions.answerA: Only when the guide dog is leading the person across the street.
questions.answerB: At all times.
questions.answerC: Only if a crossing guard is present.
questions.explanation: Pedestrians who use guide dogs or white canes (with or without a red tip) must be given the right-of-way at all times.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: One-way traffic.
questions.answerC: Limited parking.
questions.explanation: Circular traffic signs indicate upcoming railroad crossings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching a railroad crossing and should be looking for signs of an oncoming train.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Cross the centerline in an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spots by looking over your left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check for drivers trying to pass you who may be trying to enter the same lane as you. Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. You should never attempt to pass or otherwise change lanes in an intersection.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: No left turn.
questions.answerB: No U-turns.
questions.answerC: No exit.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited.

questions.question: If your car breaks down on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in your car and wait for help.
questions.answerB: Use your four-way flashers to warn other drivers.
questions.answerC: Sound your horn at passing motorists.
questions.answerD: Flash your headlights at oncoming traffic.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the highway, you should signal before carefully exiting the roadway and turning on your hazard flashers. Get as far off the road as possible and park in a location where other drivers can easily see you. Lift your hood to let other drivers know your vehicle is disabled.

questions.question: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get out of the car and go for help.
questions.answerB: Lay down in your car and go to sleep.
questions.answerC: Walk into the road and get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerD: Stay in the car, as you are most likely to be found when you stay in your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you become stranded in a snowstorm, the best thing to do is stay in your car and wait for help. You are most likely to be found if you don't leave your vehicle. Additionally, it may be unsafe to walk around outside in a snowstorm.

questions.question: Hydroplaning is usually caused by:
questions.answerA: Excessive stops.
questions.answerB: Sudden stops.
questions.answerC: Sudden turns.
questions.explanation: Your tires become less effective at clearing water from the road as you increase your speed. If you drive too fast, they may lose their grip entirely, leaving the vehicle sliding on a film of water. This is known as "hydroplaning."

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ends.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that the divided highway is about to end.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Hospital.
questions.answerB: Upcoming intersection.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming intersection so they may prepare for potential traffic or prepare to turn.

questions.question: A red arrow pointing to the right on a traffic light means you may:
questions.answerA: Turn in that direction after slowing and checking for traffic.
questions.answerB: Not turn in that direction until the light turns green.
questions.answerC: Turn in that direction after you come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A red arrow means "stop." You must remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears. Do not turn against a red arrow.

questions.question: When driving in work zones, you should:
questions.answerA: Follow the driver in front of you closely.
questions.answerB: Pass the driver in front of you as soon as you can.
questions.answerC: Avoid tailgating and keep a safe following distance.
questions.explanation: When driving in a work zone, keep a safe distance between your vehicle and traffic barriers, trucks, construction equipment, workers, and other vehicles. Increase your following distance and do not tailgate.

questions.question: Distracted drivers are at a greater risk of a crash when they are using which of the following?
questions.answerA: CD player
questions.answerB: Radio
questions.answerC: Cell phone
questions.explanation: Using a cell phone (including a hands-free phone) or any kind of audio device (including a radio or CD player) can be a dangerous distraction and contributes to the risk of a crash.

questions.question: You may honk your horn when you:
questions.answerA: Have to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Are passing another car.
questions.answerC: Have lost control of your car.
questions.explanation: One situation where it is appropriate to use your horn is if you lose control of your vehicle. In this case, sound your horn to alert other drivers.

questions.question: It is important to slow down:
questions.answerA: On narrow or winding roads.
questions.answerB: At intersections or railroad crossings.
questions.answerC: When the road is wet or slippery.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down when driving on narrow or winding roads, near intersections, near railroad crossings, on hills, in sharp or blind curves, where there are pedestrians or driving hazards, and when the roads are wet or slippery.

questions.question: When following closely behind another vehicle at night, you should use:
questions.answerA: Your high beams.
questions.answerB: Your low beams.
questions.answerC: Your parking lights.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlights when you are closer than 500 feet behind another vehicle or when in heavy traffic.

questions.question: A blood alcohol concentration of 0.02 percent:
questions.answerA: Won't have any effect on your driving.
questions.answerB: Won't put other drivers at risk.
questions.answerC: Will double your chances of having an accident.
questions.explanation: Every 0.02 percent increase in blood alcohol concentration nearly doubles a driver's risk of being in a fatal crash.

questions.question: When you see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and keep moving in your lane.
questions.answerB: Keep driving in your lane.
questions.answerC: Pull to the right curb and stop.
questions.explanation: When you see an emergency vehicle using its lights or hear it using its siren, you must immediately pull over to the curb or side of the road and stop.

questions.question: An approaching driver fails to dim their high beam headlights. Where should you look?
questions.answerA: At the wheels of the approaching vehicle.
questions.answerB: Toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Toward the left side of the road.
questions.answerD: Straight down the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: If an approaching driver fails to dim their high beams, glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course until the other vehicle has passed.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: All traffic must turn right.
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: All traffic must go straight ahead.
questions.answerD: A road joins from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection ahead. A road joins from the right.

questions.question: Under ideal driving conditions, the minimum following distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you should be:
questions.answerA: Two seconds.
questions.answerB: Four seconds.
questions.answerC: Six seconds.
questions.explanation: Leave at least four seconds worth of space between your vehicle and the vehicle directly ahead of you (under ideal driving conditions).

questions.question: If you are going to stop or slow down when another driver does not expect it:
questions.answerA: Blow your horn constantly.
questions.answerB: Wave your left arm out the window.
questions.answerC: Quickly tap the brake pedal several times.
questions.explanation: If you are going to stop or slow down at a place where another driver may not expect it, quickly tap your brake pedal three or four times. Your brake lights will indicate to other drivers that you plan to slow down.

questions.question: What should you be most concerned about when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Driving with your headlights out of alignment because one side of your car is higher than the other.
questions.answerB: Damaging a tire from drifting onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Hydroplaning, if the shoulder has water on it.
questions.answerD: Losing control of the vehicle if you drift onto the shoulder.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the shoulder is lower than the road in the area ahead. If you drift off of the roadway and one wheel drops onto a low shoulder, do not slam on the brakes or steer sharply to try to get back onto the roadway. This could easily cause you to lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: If it feels like your tires have lost contact with the surface of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down by shifting into a lower gear.
questions.answerB: Ease your foot off the gas pedal.
questions.answerC: Slow down by pumping the brakes quickly and firmly.
questions.explanation: If it feels like your tires have lost contact with the surface of the road, you should ease your foot off the gas pedal and stay off the brakes. Do not try to stop or turn until your tires are gripping the road again.

questions.question: When approaching a steady green traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving, unless there are vehicles or pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop if a police officer is nearby.
questions.answerC: Treat the intersection like a four-way stop.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a steady green traffic light, yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk and vehicles still in the intersection. You may continue driving, but should approach the intersection at a speed that will allow you to slow down and stop if the light changes before you get there.

questions.question: How can you help prevent rear-end collisions?
questions.answerA: Avoid sudden stops.
questions.answerB: Before stopping, check your mirrors and blind spots for traffic.
questions.answerC: Release the gas pedal and let your vehicle slow before applying the brakes.
questions.explanation: Stopping suddenly can make it difficult for drivers behind you to avoid a rear-end collision. When stopping, release the accelerator to allow your vehicle to slow. Press the brake pedal by applying steady pressure, activating your brake lights and causing the vehicle to stop smoothly.

questions.question: If oncoming headlights are blinding you while you are driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Look toward the right edge of the road.
questions.answerB: Switch your lights to high beams.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off.
questions.explanation: If the headlights of an oncoming vehicle are blinding, glance toward the right edge of the road instead of looking directly ahead. This should keep your vehicle safely on the road until you pass the oncoming vehicle.

questions.question: When merging onto a freeway, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Proceed slowly while waiting for an opening.
questions.answerB: Accelerate to a speed that is faster than the speed of traffic.
questions.answerC: Turn on your hazard lights until safely on the freeway.
questions.answerD: Accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When entering a freeway, use the on-ramp to accelerate to the speed of freeway traffic so you can blend in smoothly and safely. Entering traffic must yield to traffic already on the freeway.

questions.question: When two vehicles arrive to an intersection at the same time, which one has the right-of-way when no signs or signals indicate rules?
questions.answerA: The car approaching from the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The car approaching from the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: The car in which the driver sounds his horn first has the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: The car that is traveling the fastest has the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: At an intersection of two similar roads without a traffic control device, a driver must yield to a vehicle approaching from the right.

questions.question: If you are driving on a highway next to a single broken white line marking:
questions.answerA: You cannot cross the line to pass.
questions.answerB: You may cross the line to pass and change lanes.
questions.answerC: You may only cross the line to change lanes if you are in the left lane.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction. You may cross a dashed white line to pass or change lanes if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When driving on the highway, consistently looking far ahead of your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Helps you keep up with traffic.
questions.answerB: Reduces the need for last-minute braking or turning.
questions.answerC: Allows you to spot upcoming police officers.
questions.explanation: To avoid the need for last-minute braking or turning, consistently watch the road far ahead of your vehicle. By looking ahead and being ready to stop or change lanes if needed, you can drive more safely, save fuel, and help keep traffic moving at a steady pace.

questions.question: How far down the road should you look when driving?
questions.answerA: 10 to 15 seconds.
questions.answerB: 100 to 150 yards.
questions.answerC: One to two blocks.
questions.explanation: You should stay aware of conditions on the road ahead in order to avoid the need for any last-second maneuvers. Looking 10 to 15 seconds ahead of your vehicle is a good habit.

questions.question: Coming to a complete stop at an intersection, yielding to cross traffic/pedestrians, and then proceeding through the intersection when the way is clear corresponds with:
questions.answerA: A solid red light.
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light.
questions.answerC: A solid green light.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to cross traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: A speed limit is:
questions.answerA: The maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under dangerous conditions.
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions.
questions.answerC: The suggested speed to travel on a road under ideal conditions.
questions.explanation: A speed limit is the maximum or minimum legal speed you can travel on a road under ideal conditions. You may drive more slowly than the posted speed, but it is illegal to drive any faster. You must drive more slowly where signs or signs indicate a school zone or work zone speed limit. If conditions such as road construction or bad weather make the posted speed unsafe, drive under the speed limit.

questions.question: You are driving on a narrow road when you meet an oncoming vehicle. You must:
questions.answerA: Pull completely off the road and stop.
questions.answerB: Allow the oncoming vehicle at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road.
questions.answerC: Demand the other vehicle pull over to make room.
questions.answerD: Turn on your high beam headlights to make sure the other vehicle sees you.
questions.explanation: On narrow roads, you must allow vehicles traveling in the opposite direction at least one-half of the main-traveled portion of the road. Both vehicles must have adequate space in order for the drivers to safely pass one another.

questions.question: You are waiting in the intersection to complete a left turn. You should:
questions.answerA: Signal and keep your wheels turned to the left.
questions.answerB: Signal and keep your wheels straight.
questions.answerC: Flash your headlights so drivers will let you through.
questions.answerD: Drive around the rear of a car if it blocks you.
questions.explanation: You must always signal before turning or changing lanes. You should keep your wheels straight while waiting to make a left turn. If another vehicle hits you from behind, this ensures that you will not be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Drive below the posted speed limit when:
questions.answerA: Anything makes conditions less than perfect.
questions.answerB: You see a police car.
questions.answerC: Entering a highway where there are other cars.
questions.answerD: You are on a four-lane road.
questions.explanation: When the road is wet or slippery, when you cannot see well, or when anything else makes conditions less than perfect, drive below the posted speed limit. Even if you are driving within the posted speed limit, you can still be ticketed for driving too fast for conditions.

questions.question: When a pedestrian guided by a dog or carrying a white cane is crossing the street:
questions.answerA: You must always yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You must tell them where to cross the street.
questions.answerC: You only have to yield the right-of-way if you are at a corner.
questions.explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must always yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian who is using a guide dog or carrying a white cane.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerB: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerC: Winding road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a steep downhill grade is ahead.

questions.question: When changing lanes on a highway, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal a lane change.
questions.answerB: Check your rearview and outside mirrors.
questions.answerC: Check your blind spot by glancing over your shoulder.
questions.explanation: Any time you want to change lanes, you should properly signal your intentions well in advance, check your mirrors, and check your blind spot. You can check your blind spot by glancing over your shoulder in the direction that you plan to move.

questions.question: You should signal continuously while turning because it:
questions.answerA: Is illegal to turn off your signal before completing a turn.
questions.answerB: Lets other drivers know what your intentions are.
questions.answerC: Is always unsafe to turn off a signal before completing a turn.
questions.explanation: You should always signal when turning, changing lanes, slowing down, or stopping so that other drivers, motorcyclists, bicyclists, and pedestrians will know your intentions.

questions.question: When you approach a railroad crossing without flashing warning signals or crossing gates, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks immediately and as quickly as possible.
questions.answerB: Always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: Prepare to yield to any train at the crossing.
questions.answerD: Speed up to beat any oncoming train.
questions.explanation: Always be prepared to yield to any oncoming trains before crossing railroad tracks, particularly if there are no lights or gates controlling the crossing. Never start to cross the tracks until there is room for your entire vehicle on the other side of the tracks. Due to the risk of a vehicle stalling, it is not wise to shift gears when crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to:
questions.answerA: Get some coffee.
questions.answerB: Open your window.
questions.answerC: Stop driving.
questions.explanation: Being fatigued while driving is similar in danger to driving under the influence of alcohol. If you begin to feel tired while driving, the best thing to do is to stop driving.

questions.question: How can you lower the risk of hydroplaning?
questions.answerA: Do not speed when the roads are wet.
questions.answerB: Use tires with proper air pressure.
questions.answerC: Replace tires with bad tread.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning happens when a vehicle glides on top of a thin layer of water between its tires and the road. Tires with low air pressure or bad tread can increase the risk of hydroplaning. Speeding also increases the risk.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for trucks.
questions.answerB: Do not pass trucks.
questions.answerC: Truck parking area ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of the presence of a hill ahead.

questions.question: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to:
questions.answerA: Other drivers who are already in the intersection.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians who are already in the intersection.
questions.explanation: When turning left, drivers must yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic. Drivers must also always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, bicyclists, and other drivers who are already in the intersection.

questions.question: Smoking and preparing to smoke while driving:
questions.answerA: Do not affect driving abilities.
questions.answerB: Help maintain driver alertness.
questions.answerC: Are distracting activities.
questions.explanation: Smoking while driving can create dangerous distractions by causing you to take your hands off the wheel and/or your eyes off the road.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You must turn left or right.
questions.answerB: You are approaching a T intersection.
questions.answerC: The road that you are on intersects with a divided highway.
questions.answerD: You are on an overpass above a divided highway.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road that you are on intersects with a divided highway. A divided highway is two one-way roadways separated by a median or guide rail.

questions.question: A solid yellow line on your side of the centerline means:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Traffic light ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not pass.
questions.explanation: Solid yellow lines on two-lane roads indicate zones where passing is prohibited. If a solid yellow line appears next to a broken yellow line, drivers in the lane nearest to the solid yellow line may not pass. In some instances, both yellow lines will be solid, indicating that it is not safe to pass from either direction.

questions.question: If someone is driving aggressively behind you, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to get out of the aggressive driver’s way.
questions.answerB: Stare at the driver as he or she is passing you.
questions.answerC: Speed up as he or she is passing you.
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should make every attempt to get out of their way. You should avoid making eye contact with a hostile driver. Challenging a hostile driver by speeding up may only make them angrier, thereby increasing their danger.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Merge right.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins.
questions.answerC: Lane ends.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane ends ahead. A merging maneuver will be required for drivers in that lane.

questions.question: What does this road sign mean?
questions.answerA: You must turn right.
questions.answerB: No right turns permitted.
questions.answerC: Right turns permitted on a red light.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits right turns. It is illegal to turn right at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: During the first nine months that a driver under the age of 18 has a probationary license, there are restrictions regarding:
questions.answerA: The type and number of passengers that may be in their car.
questions.answerB: Their purpose for driving between midnight and 5:00 a.m.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: If you are under age 18, you may drive alone and travel anywhere from 5:00 a.m. to midnight for the first nine months that you have a probationary license. Between midnight and 5:00 a.m., you may drive alone only if traveling between your home, school, and/or workplace. Regardless of the time, there are restrictions on how many passengers you may transport and who your passengers may be.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No right turn.
questions.answerB: You must turn right.
questions.answerC: Watch for traffic on your right.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits right turns. You cannot make a right turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Blue traffic signs offer information on:
questions.answerA: Motorist services.
questions.answerB: Construction and maintenance.
questions.answerC: Mileage information, such as distances to specific locations.
questions.explanation: Blue signs on the roadway are service signs. They are used to provide information about motorist services, such as upcoming rest areas, food options, or nearby hospitals.

questions.question: A U-turn is not permitted:
questions.answerA: In a parking lot.
questions.answerB: On or near any curve or hill.
questions.answerC: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions.
questions.explanation: You must never turn around while on or near any curve or hill. You may not be able to see oncoming traffic or pedestrians and may cause a collision.

questions.question: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot when:
questions.answerA: Pulling toward or away from a curb.
questions.answerB: Turning left or right.
questions.answerC: Changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot every time you want to change your vehicle's position. If you are turning, changing lanes, or pulling toward or away from a curb, you should check your blind spots.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when tires ride on a thin film of water instead of on the surface of the road. To prevent hydroplaning in rainy weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your cruise control to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder of the road as soon as it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, you should lower your speed to reduce the risk of hydroplaning. Driving too fast may cause your tires to ride up on the water and lose contact with the surface of the road, making it very difficult to control your vehicle.

questions.question: If you are involved in a serious motor vehicle crash:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Call the police.
questions.answerC: Determine if anyone is injured.
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, move your vehicle off of the road and stop, if possible. If anyone is injured, call 911 and provide appropriate help. You must report the crash to law enforcement if there is an injury, a death, and/or more than $1,000 in property damage (or more than $200 worth of damage made to non-vehicle government property, such as signs or guardrails).

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on this road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There are a series of curves ahead.
questions.answerD: The road may be slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of an upcoming winding road with three or more curves.

questions.question: Which of the following are factors commonly contributing to traffic crashes?
questions.answerA: Exceeding the posted speed limit and driving too fast for conditions or circumstances.
questions.answerB: Getting adequate rest and staying alert.
questions.answerC: Scanning the environment and staying focused on the driving task.
questions.explanation: Driving above the speed limit, driving too far below the speed limit, and driving too fast for conditions are all actions that commonly contribute to traffic accidents. Always drive with the general flow of traffic, within legal speed limits.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop ahead.
questions.answerB: Buggy warning.
questions.answerC: Limited parking.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that there is an upcoming stop sign and that they should prepare to come to a complete stop before proceeding.

questions.question: What does a single dashed white line separating traffic mean?
questions.answerA: Drivers may pass, even if it could be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Lanes move in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: Drivers may not pass.
questions.answerD: Drivers may pass if it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines separate lanes of traffic that are moving in the same direction. Dashed white lines may be crossed to pass or change lanes, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Road rage and aggressive driving may be reduced by:
questions.answerA: Allowing extra travel time.
questions.answerB: Obeying posted speed limits.
questions.answerC: Using proper turn signals.
questions.explanation: As an increasing number of drivers populate the roadways, road rage becomes more prevalent. To help prevent road rage, a driver should use proper turn signals, obey posted speed limits, and allow plenty of travel time.

questions.question: In traffic moving at 50 to 55 mph, you are least likely to have an accident if you:
questions.answerA: Drive a few miles per hour faster than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Stay within that speed range.
questions.answerC: Drive a few miles per hour slower than most other vehicles.
questions.explanation: You should adjust your speed to travel smoothly with the other traffic on a roadway (provided that the other traffic is driving within the posted speed limits). Remember that vehicles moving in the same direction at the same speed cannot hit each other. Crashes involving multiple vehicles often happen when some vehicles are traveling at different speeds than others.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers about:
questions.answerA: Upcoming intersections.
questions.answerB: Road construction.
questions.answerC: Road curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign is used to warn drivers about an upcoming curve to the right.

questions.question: Motorcycles, scooters, and mopeds are not easy to see; therefore, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down when driving.
questions.answerB: Make constant visual checks.
questions.answerC: Share a lane with a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles can be easily hidden in a vehicle’s blind spot or missed in a quick look due to their small size. Drivers of cars must always be alert and looking for motorcycles, mopeds, and scooters.

questions.question: From the center lane, which maneuver(s) can you perform?
questions.answerA: You may make left turns.
questions.answerB: You may make U-turns.
questions.answerC: You may pass slow-moving traffic.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates where a lane is reserved for the exclusive use of left-turning vehicles from either direction. Such a lane may not be used for passing or for through-traffic.

questions.question: You have the right-of-way when turning left on which of the following traffic signals?
questions.answerA: A solid green light
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light
questions.answerC: A green arrow pointing left
questions.explanation: A green steady arrow means you may pass through the intersection in the direction that the arrow is pointing. Oncoming traffic is required to stop for turning traffic.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should:
questions.answerA: Always use your high beams.
questions.answerB: Look directly at the headlights of an oncoming vehicle.
questions.answerC: Increase your following distance.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more hazardous than daytime driving because the lowered visibility makes it difficult to judge speed, distances, and other potential hazards. Increase your following distance to help prevent a potential collision if the vehicle in front of you should stop abruptly. Use your headlights when driving at night, following the rules for proper usage of high beams and low beams.

questions.question: What do speed limit signs indicate?
questions.answerA: Potential driving speeds for the area
questions.answerB: The maximum or minimum speed that is legally allowed to be driven
questions.answerC: The speed drivers should drive in heavy traffic
questions.answerD: The speed drivers should drive under poor conditions
questions.explanation: Speed limit signs indicate the maximum or minimum safe speed that is allowed to be driven on a roadway. The maximum limits are for ideal conditions and you must reduce your speed when conditions require it.

questions.question: Downward-facing triangular signs:
questions.answerA: Indicate school zones.
questions.answerB: Tell drivers to yield.
questions.answerC: Indicate construction zones.
questions.explanation: Downward-facing triangular signs usually indicate that drivers should yield. Once the road is clear of traffic or pedestrians and it is safe to do so, drivers may proceed.

questions.question: You are involved in a minor collision at an intersection. There are no injuries and there is very little vehicle damage. You should:
questions.answerA: Leave your vehicle in the traffic lane until law enforcement arrives.
questions.answerB: Move your vehicle out of the traffic lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not move your vehicle for any reason.
questions.explanation: After a collision, if no one has been injured or killed and you can safely do so, you should move your vehicle out of the traffic lane.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You are about to enter a one-way street from the wrong direction.
questions.answerB: U-turns are prohibited.
questions.answerC: You may proceed if the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before proceeding.
questions.explanation: If you drive past these signs, you are going the wrong way and are at risk of a head-on collision. You should cautiously turn around.

questions.question: When stopping on snow or ice, drivers who are operating vehicles equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should:
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Press and hold the brake pedal firmly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes and wait for the car to drift to a stop.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), a driver should press the brake pedal firmly when stopping on a snowy or icy surface. The ABS will pump the brakes more rapidly than a driver would be able to.

questions.question: At a school crossing sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop, whether there’s a stop sign or not.
questions.answerB: Watch for children and be ready to stop.
questions.answerC: Always sound your horn when you see children.
questions.answerD: Be ready to help children crossing the street.
questions.explanation: You must always yield to pedestrians who are in or about to enter a crosswalk. Be alert to pedestrians when driving across intersections or turning.

questions.question: Where is it safe to pass another vehicle?
questions.answerA: Within an intersection where there are no oncoming vehicles
questions.answerB: Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing
questions.answerC: Within a curve where there are no oncoming vehicles
questions.explanation: Never pass within intersections or at other intersecting points, such as parking lot entrances and alleyways. Any time your view is blocked by a curve or a hill, you should stay in your lane and assume that there is an oncoming vehicle just out of sight. Wherever signs and/or pavement markings permit passing other vehicles, you will have to determine whether or not you have enough space to pass in a safe manner.

questions.question: Remove all snow, frost, and ice from:
questions.answerA: Just the windshield.
questions.answerB: All windows.
questions.answerC: Just the windshield and passenger window.
questions.explanation: It is important that you are able to see clearly through all of your vehicle's windows, including the windshield. Remove all snow, ice, and frost from your vehicle's windows and mirrors before you start to drive.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Side road.
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is an intersection with a side road ahead.
