questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren and lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, drive through the intersection first and then stop.

questions.question: If a road is slippery, maintain a following distance that is:
questions.answerA: No different than normal.
questions.answerB: Farther from the car ahead than normal.
questions.answerC: Closer to the car ahead than normal.
questions.explanation: You need a longer distance to stop your vehicle on a slippery road than you do on a dry road. Maintain an increased following distance when driving on slippery roads.

questions.question: Railroad crossings should always be considered:
questions.answerA: Safe to cross, as it is unlikely that a train will be coming.
questions.answerB: Dangerous.
questions.answerC: Safe locations to park a car.
questions.answerD: A place where it is required to stop
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings are always dangerous. Drivers should always look and listen for trains approaching from either direction on all railroad tracks. Always follow the directions indicated by signs, signals, and flaggers. Never proceed past a railroad crossing until you are certain it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Signs indicating areas of public recreation are:
questions.answerA: Orange.
questions.answerB: Red.
questions.answerC: Green.
questions.explanation: Signs that are brown indicate areas of cultural and historical significance or of public recreation. They can be a helpful resource when traveling in unfamiliar locations.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Hunting area.
questions.answerB: State park.
questions.answerC: Deer crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that deer cross the roadway in the area. You should slow down, be alert, and be ready to stop.

questions.question: You should not make sudden stops in front of large trucks and buses because:
questions.answerA: Small vehicle drivers cannot adequately see large trucks and buses in their rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Large trucks and buses, due to their size and weight, require longer distances to stop than smaller passenger vehicles.
questions.answerC: Large trucks and buses travel at a higher speeds than small vehicles.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles require longer distances to stop and accelerate than smaller vehicles do. Making a sudden stop in front of a large vehicle is dangerous because the other driver may not be able to stop in time to avoid a collision.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Side road.
questions.answerC: Two-way left turn.
questions.explanation: Eight-sided traffic signs warn drivers that they must stop and yield the appropriate right-of-way at an intersection. Drivers may proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: What does this road sign indicate?
questions.answerA: Directions for children
questions.answerB: School zone ahead
questions.answerC: Playground area ahead
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs indicate that you are in or are approaching a school zone and/or school crossing. Be aware of children when driving near a school zone and follow posted speed limits.

questions.question: Before you enter an intersection, you should look to your:
questions.answerA: Left, your right, then your left again.
questions.answerB: Right.
questions.answerC: Left.
questions.explanation: Before you enter an intersection, look to both the left and right for approaching vehicles or crossing pedestrians. Look to your left a second time, as vehicle approaching from your left will be closer than those approaching from your right. Look across the intersection before you start to move to make sure the path is clear all the way through.

questions.question: When you are merging onto the freeway, you should be driving:
questions.answerA: At or near the speed of traffic on the freeway.
questions.answerB: Five to 10 mph slower than the speed of traffic on the freeway.
questions.answerC: The posted speed limit for freeway traffic.
questions.explanation: When merging onto a freeway, you should enter at or near the speed of traffic.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead curves right. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerB: Divided highway begins. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerC: Merge. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.answerD: Winding road ahead. Slow down to the safe speed indicated.
questions.explanation: These signs indicate that the road curves to the right ahead and that drivers should slow down to the safe speed indicated (in this case, 35 mph).

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Drive with caution and be ready to stop.
questions.answerB: You must come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop, if necessary.
questions.explanation: The stop sign is the only eight-sided sign you will see on any roadway. When you encounter a stop sign, you must come to a complete stop. You may not proceed until the way is clear for you to completely and safely pass through the intersection.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid red arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Means that the traffic the arrow is pointing toward must stop.
questions.explanation: A solid red arrow in a traffic signal means the same thing as a circular red traffic light. When an arrow is red, traffic in the indicated lane must stop and may not turn in the direction that the arrow is pointing.

questions.question: If you have an argument with another person and you are angry, you should:
questions.answerA: Loudly play the radio while driving so you won’t think about your argument.
questions.answerB: Take a few minutes to cool off before driving.
questions.answerC: Drive on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.explanation: Your emotions affect your ability to drive safely. If you are overly angry, excited, afraid, worried, or depressed, you should give yourself time to calm down before operating a vehicle. You need to be able to mentally focus on driving without thinking about the things that made you upset.

questions.question: Reaction time is slower after:
questions.answerA: Drinking alcohol.
questions.answerB: Sleeping.
questions.answerC: Working hard.
questions.explanation: Alcohol slows your reflexes and reaction time, reduces your ability to see clearly, and makes you less alert. As the amount of alcohol in your body increases, your judgment worsens and your driving skills decrease. You will have trouble judging distances, speeds, and the movement of other vehicles.

questions.question: Lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions are divided by ____ lines.
questions.answerA: White
questions.answerB: Red
questions.answerC: Black
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to divide traffic moving in opposite directions.

questions.question: You should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead when you:
questions.answerA: Are following a small passenger vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are being tailgated by another driver.
questions.answerC: Are driving more slowly than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When being tailgated, create extra space in front of your vehicle and do not brake suddenly. Slow down gradually or merge into another lane to prevent a collision with the tailgater.

questions.question: "No zones" are areas around trucks where cars:
questions.answerA: Disappear into blind spots or are so close that they restrict the truck driver's ability to stop and maneuver safely.
questions.answerB: Have sufficient space to travel behind the truck.
questions.answerC: Have several car lengths between their vehicle and the truck.
questions.explanation: "No zones" are areas around trucks or buses in which cars disappear into the larger vehicle's blind spots. "No zones" can also be defined as areas in which cars are so close to the larger vehicle that they restrict the truck or bus driver’s ability to stop and maneuver safely. A car being in a "No zone" greatly increases the potential for a crash.

questions.question: When passing another car, you have enough space to return to the driving lane:
questions.answerA: If the other driver signals for you to re-enter the lane.
questions.answerB: If you look over your shoulder and see the passed car behind you.
questions.answerC: If you can see both of the passed vehicle's headlights in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before you return to the driving lane when completing a pass, be sure there is a safe gap between your vehicle and the passed vehicle. When you can see both headlights of the vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: If you have a probationary license or instructional permit, you can use your cell phone while driving:
questions.answerA: If you are just answering a call.
questions.answerB: As long as you don't text.
questions.answerC: When you are reporting an emergency.
questions.explanation: If you have a probationary license or instructional permit, using a cell phone while driving in Wisconsin is against the law. The only exception to this is if you must use your cell phone to report an emergency.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with airbags, the safest place for children age 12 and under to ride is in:
questions.answerA: The front seat.
questions.answerB: The back seat.
questions.answerC: The bed of a pick-up truck.
questions.explanation: While airbags provide supplemental protection for adults in the event of a crash, they pose a severe safety risk for children. Anyone age 12 or under should sit in the back seat of a vehicle with airbags.

questions.question: What does a traffic signal with a yellow left arrow indicate?
questions.answerA: Drivers should prepare to yield to oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The protected left turn is about to end.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: When a protected turn arrow changes from green to yellow, drivers must prepare to yield to oncoming traffic. A yellow arrow indicates that the protected left turn is ending.

questions.question: A red and white triangular sign at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white yield sign means that you must decrease speed as you approach an intersection and yield the right-of-way to any vehicles or pedestrians in the intersection. You must be prepared to stop if conditions require it.

questions.question: Stopping distances and severity of crashes:
questions.answerA: Decrease as vehicle speed increases.
questions.answerB: Are not affected by vehicle speed.
questions.answerC: Increase as vehicle speed increases.
questions.explanation: Stopping distances are longer and crashes are more severe when traffic travels at higher speeds.

questions.question: If an oncoming driver is heading toward you in your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Blow your horn, steer right, and accelerate.
questions.answerB: Blow your horn, steer left, and brake.
questions.answerC: Blow your horn, steer right, and brake.
questions.answerD: Stay in the center of your lane, blow your horn, and brake.
questions.explanation: If another vehicle is approaching you head-on in your lane, you should first honk your horn to attract attention. If the other driver does not move over, try to escape to the right. If you swerve left and the other driver corrects at the last instant, you will still crash. If a collision is unavoidable, brake firmly and steadily. Every mile per hour you slow down will reduce the impact.

questions.question: The risk of hydroplaning can can be reduced by driving:
questions.answerA: Through shallow water.
questions.answerB: More quickly.
questions.answerC: More slowly.
questions.explanation: Because hydroplaning is caused by driving too quickly in wet conditions, the risk of it happening can be reduced by driving more slowly.

questions.question: If you are driving near a large commercial vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Follow the large vehicle closely to reduce wind drag on your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Avoid driving beside it for long stretches of time.
questions.answerC: Drive on its right side when on curves and hills.
questions.explanation: Because large commercial vehicles have large blind spots on each side, you should avoid driving beside them for long periods of time.

questions.question: A blood alcohol concentration of 0.02 percent:
questions.answerA: Won't have any effect on your driving.
questions.answerB: Won't put other drivers at risk.
questions.answerC: Will double your chances of having an accident.
questions.explanation: Every 0.02 percent increase in blood alcohol concentration nearly doubles a driver's risk of being in a fatal crash.

questions.question: To reduce the effects of headlight glare at night, you should look:
questions.answerA: Straight ahead.
questions.answerB: Over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: At the center of the road
questions.answerD: To the right edge of the road.
questions.explanation: If oncoming drivers do not dim their headlights for you, keep your eyes on the right side of the road ahead. Do not look directly at the oncoming headlights because the glare may blind you for several seconds.

questions.question: A flashing red traffic light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: The same thing as a yield sign.
questions.answerB: The light is about to turn green.
questions.answerC: The same thing as a stop sign.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light at an intersection means drivers are required to come to a complete stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when the way is clear. The same is true at a stop sign.

questions.question: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Go the same speed.
questions.answerC: Slow down to allow room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete the pass easily.
questions.explanation: When the driver behind you wants to pass, you should slow down so that there is enough room in front of your vehicle for the other driver to complete their pass. This will allow them to complete the passing maneuver in less time and more easily.

questions.question: Night driving presents unique problems because:
questions.answerA: The speed limit is increased at night.
questions.answerB: There are fewer cars on the roads at night.
questions.answerC: Distance and vehicle speed are difficult to judge in the dark.
questions.explanation: Night driving creates a unique set of problems for drivers. Due to the reduced visibility, it can be difficult to judge distance and the traveling speeds of other vehicles when driving at night. Drivers can see only as far as their headlights allow.

questions.question: If someone has consumed alcoholic drinks, what will help the person overcome the influence of those drinks?
questions.answerA: Tomato juice and lime
questions.answerB: Hot coffee
questions.answerC: Fresh air
questions.explanation: Only the passage of time will allow a person to overcome the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: This sign tells you that:
questions.answerA: No turns are allowed on the road.
questions.answerB: The road narrows ahead.
questions.answerC: There is a series of curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about an upcoming winding road.

questions.question: Two solid yellow lines on the pavement mean:
questions.answerA: Passing is allowed for drivers from both directions.
questions.answerB: Passing is not allowed.
questions.answerC: Passing is allowed if you are at the top a hill.
questions.answerD: Passing is allowed during daylight only.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines tell you that the traffic on the other side of the lines is moving in the opposite direction. You should never cross two solid yellow lines to pass from either direction.

questions.question: When turning left at an intersection:
questions.answerA: You should always yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerB: Oncoming traffic and pedestrians should yield to you.
questions.answerC: You should never yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.explanation: Drivers making left turns must yield to oncoming traffic that is traveling straight. Drivers must always yield to pedestrians.

questions.question: You should yield to a pedestrian:
questions.answerA: Only if they are in a crosswalk.
questions.answerB: At all times, even if the pedestrian is not obeying traffic laws.
questions.answerC: Only if the traffic lights are in the pedestrian's favor.
questions.explanation: Always be aware of pedestrians near your vehicle. You must do everything you can to prevent striking a pedestrian, regardless of the circumstances.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Four-lane traffic ahead.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns that you are leaving a separated one-way highway and will soon be driving on a two-way highway.

questions.question: Driving more slowly than surrounding traffic is:
questions.answerA: A good idea if the weather is bad.
questions.answerB: Appropriate if you don’t know the speed limit.
questions.answerC: Often a hazard because other drivers may become frustrated and try to pass you.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than other traffic can be dangerous. Drivers behind you may become impatient and will be tempted to take dangerous risks to pass you.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Use your parking lights.
questions.answerC: Use your low beam headlights.
questions.explanation: Drivers should use low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beams will reflect back at the driver, making it difficult to see.

questions.question: When driving on gravel or dirt roads:
questions.answerA: Your tires grip the road better than when you are driving on pavement.
questions.answerB: Your tires do not have as much traction as they do on pavement, so you must slow down.
questions.answerC: Visibility is better than on pavement.
questions.explanation: Your tires do not have as much traction on loose gravel and dirt roads as they do on concrete and asphalt roads. When driving on gravel or dirt, you must slow down. It will take you much longer to stop and it is much easier to skid when turning.

questions.question: You want to back out of your driveway. You see children playing nearby. Before you start to move your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Rev your engine to warn the children that you are moving.
questions.answerB: Sound your horn so the children will hear you.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the car to be sure the way is clear.
questions.answerD: Tell the children to stay away from the driveway.
questions.explanation: When you back up a vehicle, look through your back window for pedestrians and other obstacles. Do not rely only on your mirrors, especially when children are near. Before you back into or out of a driveway, get out of the vehicle and check behind your vehicle.

questions.question: You are driving on a one-way street. You may only turn left onto another one-way street if:
questions.answerA: You increase your speed before the turn.
questions.answerB: Traffic on the street moves to the right.
questions.answerC: Traffic on the street moves to the left.
questions.explanation: You may turn left onto a one-way street that moves to the left if there is no sign prohibiting the turn. You may not turn left onto a one-way street where traffic moves to the right.

questions.question: At intersections with a "Yield" sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is near enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way only to vehicles on your right.
questions.answerC: Always slow down and proceed without stopping.
questions.explanation: At a yield sign, you must slow down or stop, if necessary, and give the right-of-way to crossing or merging vehicles. Yield the right-of-way to any cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for people crossing your path.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Work zone ahead.
questions.explanation: This orange warning sign tells drivers that an area of roadwork is upcoming. When traveling through a work zone, stay alert for temporary traffic control devices.

questions.question: When driving under low-visibility conditions due to fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on your high beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Increase your speed so you do not cause an accident.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam lights. If the fog is so dense that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: The effect that lack of sleep has on your safe driving ability is the same as:
questions.answerA: The effect that alcohol has.
questions.answerB: The effect that amphetamines have.
questions.answerC: The effect that anger has.
questions.answerD: The effect that driving with teenagers has.
questions.explanation: Fatigue and being under the influence of alcohol have similar effects on your ability to drive safely. For example, being awake for 18 hours impairs your driving about as much as a blood alcohol level of 0.05 percent. Being awake for 24 hours in a row has the same effect on your driving as a blood alcohol level of 0.10 percent.

questions.question: If you see a pedestrian using a guide dog or carrying a white cane:
questions.answerA: The pedestrian must yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: You must yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn to let them know you are there.
questions.explanation: Blind or partially blind pedestrians may carry a white cane or use the assistance of a guide dog. You must yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian with a guide dog or a white cane.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Watch for traffic merging from the right.
questions.answerB: Merge right.
questions.answerC: Turn left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs alert drivers to upcoming hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about potential traffic merging into their lane from the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Left turn yield on green.
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Cattle crossing.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If a child is about to run into the street, you should:
questions.answerA: Start to prepare to slow down.
questions.answerB: Flash your headlights.
questions.answerC: Sound a sharp blast of your horn.
questions.explanation: If there is danger, you may need to sound a sharp blast on your horn. Do this when a child or any other pedestrian is about to enter into the street in front of your moving vehicle.

questions.question: Which statement is true?
questions.answerA: You should put on your cruise control near a railroad crossing to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger or stop sign.
questions.answerC: You have the right-of-way at a railroad crossing and do not need to stop.
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when directed to do so by a flagger, stop sign, or warning signal. Use caution when driving near railroad tracks.

questions.question: If the traffic light is red and you want to turn right, you can turn:
questions.answerA: When the cross traffic has cleared.
questions.answerB: After you stop.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign prohibits it, you may turn right at a red light after coming to a complete stop. When turning on red, you must yield to other traffic, pedestrians, and bicyclists before proceeding.

questions.question: What is the maximum speed limit in residential and business areas where there are no posted speed limits?
questions.answerA: 15 mph
questions.answerB: 25 mph
questions.answerC: 35 mph
questions.explanation: Unless otherwise posted, the speed limit on residential and business streets is 25 miles per hour.

questions.question: You must yield to other drivers:
questions.answerA: When entering a street from a garage or alley.
questions.answerB: When they are on a road to your left and you have reached an unmarked intersection at the same time.
questions.answerC: When your traffic signal is a green arrow.
questions.explanation: You must yield to other drivers when entering a street from an alley, driveway, or garage. You must also yield to pedestrians who are on an intersecting sidewalk.

questions.question: When changing lanes you should not:
questions.answerA: Check your side and rearview mirrors.
questions.answerB: Give a turn signal to signal your intentions.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers who may be moving into the same lane as you.
questions.answerD: Use your cell phone to contact the police to determine if the road ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check your side and rearview mirrors for traffic approaching you from behind. Use your turn signal to let other drivers know you plan to change lanes. Check for other drivers who also may be moving into the same lane.

questions.question: Roads with double solid yellow line markings down the center indicate that passing is:
questions.answerA: Allowed from both directions.
questions.answerB: Allowed only from your direction of travel.
questions.answerC: Not allowed from either direction.
questions.explanation: A double solid yellow line down the center of a road indicates that traffic is moving in opposite directions and that passing is not allowed from either direction.

questions.question: To safely pass a bicycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Honk at the bicyclist to let them know you're trying to pass.
questions.answerB: Drive in the bicycle lane until you get a chance to pass.
questions.answerC: Slow down and give them as much space as possible.
questions.answerD: Rush ahead to pull in front of the bicyclist.
questions.explanation: When passing a bicyclist, slow down and give them as much space as you can. Bicyclists have much less protection than drivers of motor vehicles and they should not be crowded. Passing a bicycle too quickly can shift the bicyclist off-course.

questions.question: A red flashing traffic light has the same meaning as a:
questions.answerA: Solid red light.
questions.answerB: Stop sign.
questions.answerC: Yield sign.
questions.explanation: A red flashing traffic signal has the same meaning as a stop sign. When approaching a red flashing signal, come to a complete stop and proceed when it is safe to do so. A stop sign may sometimes also be posted where this signal is located.

questions.question: A single broken yellow line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: The law requires you to stay at least how far behind an active snowplow with its red or amber lights on?
questions.answerA: 200 feet
questions.answerB: 300 feet
questions.answerC: 400 feet
questions.explanation: On roads with a posted speed limit of 35 mph or more, the law requires drivers to stay at least 200 feet behind a working snowplow when its red or amber lights are on.

questions.question: After you have passed a vehicle moving in the same direction, it is safe to move back into the right lane:
questions.answerA: After about three seconds.
questions.answerB: When you can no longer see the passed vehicle over your right shoulder.
questions.answerC: When you can see the entire front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: When passing, you should not return to your original lane until you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. Always check your blind spots before moving back into your original lane.

questions.question: A school bus is stopped ahead of you in your lane with its red lights flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and proceed when you think all of the children have exited the bus.
questions.answerB: Slow to 25 mph and pass cautiously.
questions.answerC: Stop for as long as the red lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: When a stopped school bus is using its flashing red lights, approaching drivers must stop and remain stopped until the lights stop flashing. If the school bus is on the opposite side of a divided highway, drivers do not need to stop.

questions.question: A large truck is ahead of you and is turning right onto a street with two lanes in each direction. The truck:
questions.answerA: May complete its turn in either of the two lanes.
questions.answerB: May have to swing wide to complete the right turn.
questions.answerC: Must stay in the right lane at all times while turning.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle makes a turn, the rear wheels follow a shorter path than the front wheels. The longer the vehicle, the bigger the difference between the paths of the front and rear wheels. Therefore, long trucks often have to swing wide to complete a right turn.

questions.question: You experience an incident at work that has left you feeling angry. When you get to your car, you should:
questions.answerA: Play the radio loudly so you won’t think about it.
questions.answerB: Drive fast on the interstate to let off steam.
questions.answerC: Take a few minutes to cool off before you begin your drive home.
questions.answerD: Stop at your favorite bar and have a few drinks before driving home.
questions.explanation: Persons who are upset, angry, or otherwise distracted by their emotions should take time to cool off before driving a car. Taking out frustrations or anger while driving is exercising very poor judgment and is very dangerous to both the driver and others on the road.

questions.question: You may avoid the risks of alcohol-related crashes by:
questions.answerA: Deciding before you start drinking that you are not going to drive.
questions.answerB: Simply saying, "No thanks, I'm driving," if someone offers you a drink.
questions.answerC: Calling a taxi.
questions.explanation: The only way to avoid the risks of drinking and driving is to decide before you start drinking that you are not going to drive. Because alcohol affects your judgement, it will be harder for you to make safe decisions after you have started drinking.

questions.question: When parking your vehicle on any hill:
questions.answerA: One of your rear wheels should touch the curb.
questions.answerB: Use your parking brake and leave the vehicle in "park."
questions.answerC: Your front wheels should be parallel to the road, if there is no curb.
questions.explanation: When parking on a hill, you should always leave your vehicle in gear or in the "park" position. If there is no curb, you should turn your front wheels so that the vehicle will roll away from the center of the road if the brakes fail. If there is a curb, the front wheels should be turned toward it (if headed downhill) or away from and gently touching it (if headed uphill).

questions.question: When getting ready to change lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Check your side view mirror.
questions.answerB: Check your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Quickly turn your head to check for other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check your side and rearview mirrors for traffic approaching you from behind. Just before you begin moving into the other lane, quickly glance over your shoulder and check for any vehicles that may be in your blind spot.

questions.question: If you’re going to turn left onto a one-way street, you should complete the turn into:
questions.answerA: The right lane.
questions.answerB: The lane closest to your previous lane.
questions.answerC: Either lane.
questions.explanation: You should always turn from the lane that is closest to the direction you want to go. Turn into the lane closest to your previous lane.

questions.question: A broken yellow centerline indicates that:
questions.answerA: Passing is not permitted.
questions.answerB: Passing on the right is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.answerC: Passing on the left is permitted when the way ahead is clear.
questions.explanation: A broken yellow centerline next to your side of the road indicates that traffic may cross the centerline to pass from your side of the road.

questions.question: To help prevent crashes, you should:
questions.answerA: Communicate with other road users.
questions.answerB: Ignore other drivers on the road.
questions.answerC: Drive only on side streets and back roads.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen because one driver does something that other road users are not expecting. You should communicate with other motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians by doing things like signaling when slowing down, stopping, or changing direction. Use your emergency signals or horn when appropriate.

questions.question: If your turn signals fail, you should use ____ to indicate that you are turning.
questions.answerA: Your horn
questions.answerB: Your headlights
questions.answerC: Hand signals
questions.explanation: If your vehicle's turn signals do not work, you should use hand signals to indicate when you intend to change direction.

questions.question: If it is necessary to make an emergency stop while driving on an interstate, you should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn at passing cars to get their attention.
questions.answerB: Get out of your vehicle and flag down the first vehicle that passes.
questions.answerC: Pull off the road, turn on your emergency flashers, and stay in your vehicle, if you can.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the shoulder of the interstate or highway, turn on your emergency flashers to warn other drivers and stay inside your vehicle, if you can. The extremely high speed of traffic makes standing or walking along an interstate highway very dangerous.

questions.question: When should drivers yield the right-of-way to pedestrians in a crosswalk?
questions.answerA: Only if the pedestrians first wave to the driver.
questions.answerB: Only if the pedestrians are not texting while walking.
questions.answerC: At all times.
questions.explanation: Bring your vehicle to a complete stop at a crosswalk to yield the right-of-way to any vehicle or pedestrian already in the intersection. You may carefully proceed if your lane is completely clear.

questions.question: If your vehicle has a two-part safety belt system, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the lap belt.
questions.answerB: Use both the lap and shoulder belts.
questions.answerC: Use only the shoulder belt.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has a two-part seat belt system, be sure to wear both the lap belt and the shoulder belt. Wearing either part alone greatly reduces your protection. If you have an automatic shoulder belt, be sure to buckle your lap belt as well.

questions.question: To see vehicles in your blind spots, you should check:
questions.answerA: The inside rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: The outside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Over your shoulders.
questions.explanation: By definition, blind spots are areas that cannot be seen using your mirrors. To check your blind spots, you should look over your shoulders.

questions.question: You need to use extra caution when driving near a pedestrian using a white cane because:
questions.answerA: He or she is deaf.
questions.answerB: He or she is a police officer.
questions.answerC: He or she is blind.
questions.answerD: He or she has poor balance.
questions.explanation: When driving near a blind pedestrian who is carrying a white cane or walking with a guide dog, you must slow down, yield the right-of-way, and then proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop your vehicle in order to prevent injury or danger to the pedestrian.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: No passing zone.
questions.answerC: Reduction in lanes.
questions.explanation: A triangular red and white sign indicates that you must yield the right-of-way.

questions.question: You are driving when it begins to rain. You should:
questions.answerA: Drive faster than surrounding traffic.
questions.answerB: Drive at the maximum posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.answerD: Drive closely behind the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: When heavy rain reduces visibility, reduce your speed. Turn on your headlights so other drivers can see your vehicle. If the rain is so heavy that you are unable to see clearly, drive onto the shoulder and stop until the rain lets up.

questions.question: At a school crossing sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop, whether there is a stop sign or not.
questions.answerB: Watch for children and be ready to stop.
questions.answerC: Always sound your horn when you see children.
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs mean you are approaching a school zone and/or school crossing. When you see these signs, be alert and prepare to stop.

questions.question: When may you proceed through an intersection that has a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk?
questions.answerA: After slowing down to verify that there is no cross traffic
questions.answerB: After coming to a complete stop and verifying that it is safe to proceed
questions.answerC: After you have stopped at least 20 feet prior to the intersection
questions.answerD: After slowing down to a speed of 10 mph
questions.explanation: Stop before the stop line or crosswalk at any intersection that is controlled by a stop sign. If there is a stop sign but no stop line or crosswalk, stop before entering the intersection and proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A sign with this shape means:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing.
questions.answerB: Warning.
questions.answerC: Signal ahead.
questions.explanation: A diamond-shaped yellow sign warns of possible danger ahead. Orange signs, which are mostly diamond-shaped, are used to warn of possible dangers in or near work areas.

questions.question: It is necessary to use your low beams any time you are:
questions.answerA: On a lighted street.
questions.answerB: On a freeway.
questions.answerC: In fog.
questions.explanation: Use your low beams when driving in fog, snow, rain, or mist. Light from high beams will reflect off of precipitation, causing a glare and making it even more difficult to see. Some vehicles are equipped with fog lights that should be used in addition to low beam headlights.

questions.question: Which of the following driving skills are affected by the use of alcohol and/or drugs?
questions.answerA: Alertness and concentration.
questions.answerB: Reaction time and coordination.
questions.answerC: All of the above.
questions.explanation: Any amount of alcohol acts as a depressant, slowing the function of the nervous system. It will reduce a person's alertness and ability to concentrate, increase their reaction time, and drastically reduce their coordination.

questions.question: On long trips, you can prevent drowsiness by:
questions.answerA: Turning on your car radio.
questions.answerB: Slowing down.
questions.answerC: Stopping at regular intervals for a rest.
questions.answerD: Moving your eyes from side to side as you drive.
questions.explanation: To prevent drowsiness on long trips, you should schedule regular stops. Give yourself time to rest and stretch, even if you are not feeling tired.

questions.question: If your vehicle begins to skid, you should:
questions.answerA: Overcorrect.
questions.answerB: Turn your steering wheel into traffic.
questions.answerC: Turn your steering wheel in the direction you want to go.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, remain calm. Steer in the direction that you want to go and try not to overcorrect.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Tap or pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Slow down gradually and use your brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly and quickly.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, you should slow down gradually by taking your foot off of the accelerator. Don't apply the brakes until the vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: Alcohol is:
questions.answerA: A stimulant.
questions.answerB: An antihistamine.
questions.answerC: A depressant.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant that dulls your judgment and makes your reflexes unreliable.

questions.question: When driving past a vehicle that has just stopped in a parked position on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume that the driver will open the car door as you approach.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerD: Assume that the driver will wait for you to pass before opening the door.
questions.explanation: When passing a vehicle that has just parked parallel to the road, you should assume the driver will open the door as you approach. Use extra caution when driving near parked vehicles.

questions.question: On a two-lane street, your vehicle is being followed by a fire engine that is not using its emergency signals. You should:
questions.answerA: Continue to drive in a normal manner.
questions.answerB: Stop as quickly as you can.
questions.answerC: Speed up to get out of its way.
questions.answerD: Slow down, move as far to the right as possible, and stop.
questions.explanation: If you are being followed by an emergency vehicle that is not using its siren or flashing lights, you do not need to clear a path. Continue driving in a normal manner.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerA: Don’t make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Don't react with hand gestures.
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: A red arrow displayed on a traffic light means that:
questions.answerA: A driver must proceed slowly through the intersection.
questions.answerB: A driver must stop and then proceed when the way is clear.
questions.answerC: A driver must stop and then proceed when the signal changes to a green light or green arrow.
questions.answerD: A driver may turn in the direction that the red arrow is pointing.
questions.explanation: Unless a posted sign indicates otherwise, a traffic signal displaying a red arrow means that drivers must come to a full stop and remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears.

questions.question: You are merging onto an interstate highway. You should:
questions.answerA: Select a safe gap and merge into the lane of traffic.
questions.answerB: Merge across two lanes at once.
questions.answerC: Always stop before entering the highway.
questions.explanation: Anytime you want to merge with other drivers, you need to find a gap large enough for you to safely enter into the flow of traffic. You should not stop on the entrance ramp to an interstate highway unless there are no gaps into which you may safely merge.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection when the traffic light changes from green to solid yellow. You should:
questions.answerA: Consider it the same as a caution sign and continue through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Stop immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection, unless you are too close to stop safely.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get through the intersection before the red light appears.
questions.explanation: When approaching an intersection with a solid yellow traffic light, slow to a stop before entering the intersection, if it is safe to do so. If you can't stop safely, drive carefully through the intersection.

questions.question: Another driver is trying to pass your car. You should:
questions.answerA: Pull off the road.
questions.answerB: Signal to the other driver when it is safe for them to pass.
questions.answerC: Check for oncoming traffic and adjust your speed to allow safe passing.
questions.explanation: Keep right when another driver begins to pass you on the left. Check for oncoming traffic and adjust your speed to let the passing vehicle move back into the right lane as easily as possible.

questions.question: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other:
questions.answerA: It is always safe to proceed after one train passes.
questions.answerB: You must always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: When one train passes, look for another train on the other track before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn as you cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other, watch for a second approaching train after one train passes. Do not begin to cross the tracks until you’re sure no train is approaching from either direction on either track.

questions.question: Drowsy drivers:
questions.answerA: Should drink strong black coffee to stay awake.
questions.answerB: Can drive so poorly that they may appear to be drunk.
questions.answerC: Can stay alert by opening a window and turning up the radio.
questions.explanation: Drowsiness can make people drive so poorly that they appear to be drunk. Opening a window, turning on the radio, or drinking coffee is not enough to make a drowsy driver alert to roadway hazards.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: Where this sign is posted, it is prohibited to make a right turn. It would be unsafe and unlawful to make a right turn at an intersection with this sign.

questions.question: The Implied Consent Law in Wisconsin means that:
questions.answerA: Drivers under age 21 cannot drive after drinking any alcohol.
questions.answerB: Penalties become more severe after a first OWI conviction.
questions.answerC: Drivers must submit to alcohol testing when requested by a police officer.
questions.answerD: A second OWI conviction requires your vehicle to have an ignition interlock device.
questions.explanation: The Implied Consent Law means that by driving in Wisconsin, you consent to taking an alcohol test upon request. If you refuse, you will be arrested for violating the Implied Consent Law. Violation of this law will result in loss of your driving privileges for at least a year, in addition to other penalties.

questions.question: Work zone signs mean:
questions.answerA: It is summer.
questions.answerB: You must immediately stop and back up.
questions.answerC: Less than ideal conditions are present for driving.
questions.answerD: You should drive faster to get out of the work zone.
questions.explanation: Work zone signs are orange and indicate that some type of work is being performed on or alongside the roadway. Be extremely careful when you see these signs.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Do not drink and drive.
questions.answerB: Slippery when wet.
questions.answerC: Road curves ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns that the roadway is slippery when wet.

questions.question: If you experience a tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Take your foot of the gas.
questions.answerB: Do not immediately use your brakes.
questions.answerC: Gradually slow down and pull off the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, take your foot off the gas pedal and do not immediately apply the brakes. Gradually slow down before gently applying the brakes and pulling off the side of the road.

questions.question: If a tire blows out, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brake and hold it.
questions.answerB: Hold the steering wheel tightly and use the brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Pull over quickly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly blows out while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle going straight.You should slow down gradually, taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly. Do not stop on the road if at all possible. Pull off the road in a safe place.

questions.question: As you near an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. Your best action is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes sharply to stop.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop in the center of the intersection.
questions.answerD: Be prepared to stop before the intersection.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that the light will soon change to red. You should be prepared to stop for the red light, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Give the right-of-way to any pedestrian who is:
questions.answerA: In a marked crosswalk.
questions.answerB: In any crosswalk or intersection.
questions.answerC: Crossing any street.
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield the right-of-way to pedestrians who are crossing the street in any marked or unmarked crosswalk. In the interest of safety, drivers should yield the right-of-way to people crossing any street.

questions.question: The sign with this shape and color is a ____ sign.
questions.answerA: No passing zone
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped warning signs like this are only used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: Certain highway signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Such signs are known as:
questions.answerA: Regulatory signs.
questions.answerB: Warning signs.
questions.answerC: Information signs.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs require drivers to obey an indicated instruction. Failure to comply is subject to penalty.

questions.question: Drivers who have consumed alcohol before getting behind the wheel:
questions.answerA: Are always aware of the risks they are taking.
questions.answerB: Do not have sufficient control over their bodies and minds or the vehicles being driven.
questions.answerC: Are better drivers because they are more careful than sober drivers.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant that negatively affects judgment, vision, concentration, understanding of reality, and reaction time. It is never safe to consume alcohol in any amount before getting behind the wheel of a car.

questions.question: Motorcycles are entitled to:
questions.answerA: The bicycle lane.
questions.answerB: The same full lane width as other motor vehicles.
questions.answerC: Half the width of a lane.
questions.explanation: Lane usage for the motorcyclist is critical. Motorcycles are entitled to the same full lane width as all other vehicles.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You are approaching the end of a divided highway.
questions.answerB: You are approaching the beginning of a divided highway.
questions.answerC: The road will be slippery ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead. Keep to the right of the median divider.

questions.question: Which statement about speed is true?
questions.answerA: Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous.
questions.answerB: Speeding can kill.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not dangerous if you are a skilled driver.
questions.answerD: Both "Driving too slowly on certain highways can be dangerous" and "Speeding can kill."
questions.explanation: As speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases. If you are moving faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. Driving more slowly than other traffic can also be dangerous because other motorists may become impatient and make dangerous moves to pass you.

questions.question: When driving on major highways:
questions.answerA: Stay alert.
questions.answerB: Keep your eyes moving.
questions.answerC: Be ready to react to road hazards.
questions.explanation: It is important to stay alert on highways and be ready to react to unexpected hazards. To avoid "highway hypnosis," you should avoid looking at any one thing for more than a few seconds.

questions.question: How far ahead of an intended turn should you activate your turn signal?
questions.answerA: 25 feet
questions.answerB: 50 feet
questions.answerC: 75 feet
questions.explanation: You should signal 100 feet before you intend to turn. However, you should be careful if there are other streets, driveways, or entrances between your current location and the location of the turn. Wait to activate your turn signal until there are no other possible turns between you and your desired turning location.

questions.question: Which of the following influence(s) the effects of alcohol?
questions.answerA: The amount of food in the stomach
questions.answerB: The body weight of an individual
questions.answerC: How much time passes between drinks
questions.explanation: Your blood alcohol content (BAC) depends on how much alcohol you drink, how much time passes between drinks, and your weight. Eating before or while you drink helps slow the absorption of alcohol somewhat, but it cannot prevent intoxication or impairment if you have too much to drink.

questions.question: The most common color of warning signs is:
questions.answerA: Red.
questions.answerB: Yellow.
questions.answerC: Green.
questions.explanation: Most warning signs are diamond-shaped and yellow with black markings. These signs warn drivers about unexpected conditions that may not be readily apparent.

questions.question: You notice that the driver in the vehicle ahead of you is driving with one hand and talking to a passenger. You should:
questions.answerA: Give the vehicle extra space.
questions.answerB: Know that the driver in the vehicle ahead is reducing their safety margin by being an inattentive driver.
questions.answerC: Avoid following the driver's example.
questions.explanation: Do not become distracted by looking at passengers, attempting to find something in your vehicle, looking at reading material, sightseeing, or daydreaming while driving. If a driver near you seems distracted, allow them extra space because the risk of an accident is increased by their inattentiveness.

questions.question: At an intersection with a yield sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: Yield just to the traffic on the right.
questions.answerC: Yield just to the traffic on the left.
questions.answerD: Slow down and yield the right-of-way to other traffic.
questions.explanation: A yield sign means that you must slow down and yield the right-of-way to traffic in the intersection or roadway you are entering.

questions.question: You are driving in the left lane and want to move into the right lane. You should:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over your left shoulder for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over your right shoulder for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerC: Check your mirrors, signal, and look over both shoulders for other vehicles before changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Check your mirrors, signal, and change lanes.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, you should check your vehicle's blind spots by looking over your shoulder in the direction that you want to move. Always check your mirrors and turn on your directional signal before beginning a lane change.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down if an emergency vehicle is approaching.
questions.answerB: Look both ways as you cross the intersection.
questions.answerC: Always come to a full stop at the intersection.
questions.answerD: Slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions.explanation: Decrease your speed as you approach an intersection with a yield sign. Prepare to stop and yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians in the intersection or crossroad. You must come to a full stop at a yield sign if traffic conditions require it.

questions.question: If you want to pass a pedestrian who is walking along the roadway and an oncoming vehicle is approaching, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and let the oncoming vehicle pass before you pass the pedestrian.
questions.answerB: Keep driving at a steady speed. The oncoming vehicle must stop for you.
questions.answerC: Honk your horn to get the pedestrian to move over.
questions.explanation: If possible, try to only deal with one roadway hazard at a time. If you want to pass a pedestrian but an oncoming vehicle is approaching, slow down and let the vehicle pass. You may then pass the pedestrian if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Broken yellow lines are used on streets and highways to:
questions.answerA: Indicate no passing zones.
questions.answerB: Separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction.
questions.answerC: Separate lanes of traffic moving in opposite directions.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines on the pavement indicate that passing is permitted when safe.

questions.question: Traffic signs and pavement markings:
questions.answerA: Must always be obeyed.
questions.answerB: Are merely suggestions.
questions.answerC: Must be followed only when there is other traffic.
questions.answerD: Must be followed only when a police officer is present.
questions.explanation: Traffic flow is controlled by pavement markings, traffic islands, signals, and signs. These devices inform drivers of conditions on the roadway and help guide drivers safely to their destinations. You must always obey traffic signs, signals, and pavement markings.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: Rely on the rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move.
questions.answerC: Rely on the left side mirror.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, glance over your shoulder to check for traffic in your blind spot. You may need to look several times before changing lanes. You must keep track of what traffic is doing in front of you as well as what traffic is doing in the lane next to you.

questions.question: If a truck or bus is making a right turn where you also need to make a right turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly turn before the truck or bus is able to.
questions.answerB: Wait until the truck or bus turns before you turn.
questions.answerC: Squeeze between the truck or bus and the curb.
questions.explanation: If you try to insert your vehicle between a turning truck or bus and a curb, you may suffer a serious crash. To avoid a collision, do not turn until the truck or bus has completed its turn.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Continue at your current speed.
questions.answerB: You must stop ahead.
questions.answerC: Speeding is not allowed.
questions.answerD: There is a traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a traffic signal ahead.

questions.question: When passing other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn at least three times.
questions.answerC: Re-enter your lane within 10 feet of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing another vehicle, check your mirrors and blind spots. Before changing lanes, activate the appropriate turn signal. Re-enter the lane when you can see the front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: The proper way to make a right turn is to:
questions.answerA: Signal, slow down, and get into the lane closest to the centerline before turning.
questions.answerB: Signal, slow down, and get into the lane closest to the right curb before turning.
questions.answerC: Approach the corner in the lane nearest the right curb, but move over toward the middle of the street before turning.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a right turn, use the appropriate signal to give surrounding drivers adequate notice of your intentions. Slow down and approach the intersection from the right lane, staying as close as is practical to the right curb or edge of the roadway.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Steep grade ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Low ground railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the overpass ahead has a low clearance. You should not proceed if your vehicle is taller than the height shown on the sign (in this case, 13 feet 6 inches).

questions.question: This road sign indicates:
questions.answerA: The maximum safe speed for a residential area.
questions.answerB: The maximum safe speed for an expressway exit.
questions.answerC: The maximum safe speed for an expressway entrance.
questions.answerD: The maximum safe speed for a work zone.
questions.explanation: This advisory speed sign indicates the maximum safe speed for a highway exit (in this example, 30 mph).

questions.question: When driving in fog or mist, never put your headlights on the high beam setting because:
questions.answerA: The light will reflect back into your eyes.
questions.answerB: Approaching vehicles might not see you.
questions.answerC: Vehicles behind you may follow too closely.
questions.explanation: In foggy or misty conditions, you should not use your headlights on their high beam setting because the light will be reflected back into your eyes.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing yellow light. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and wait for the light to change.
questions.answerB: Make a U-turn because the intersection is closed.
questions.answerC: Drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Prepare to stop; the light is about to turn red.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means that you should proceed through the intersection slowly and with caution. Scan your eyes across traffic in both directions.

questions.question: If a child is riding a bicycle near your vehicle:
questions.answerA: Beep your horn.
questions.answerB: Expect the child to be in total control of the bicycle.
questions.answerC: Expect the unexpected.
questions.explanation: Children on bicycles are sometimes unpredictable. Young bicyclists are especially likely to make surprising changes in direction. Remember that children and bicycles are both small in stature and may become difficult to see.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerA: Red, yellow, green.
questions.answerB: Red, green, yellow.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers about the presence of traffic signals at an intersection ahead.

questions.question: Extra space in front of a large truck is needed for:
questions.answerA: Other drivers to merge onto the freeway.
questions.answerB: The truck driver to stop the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Other drivers when they want to slow down.
questions.explanation: Because they are larger, trucks take longer to stop than cars traveling at the same speed. Other drivers should not pull in front of a truck and then slow down or stop.

questions.question: When following closely behind another vehicle at night, you should use:
questions.answerA: Your high beams.
questions.answerB: Your low beams.
questions.answerC: Your parking lights.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlights when you are closer than 500 feet behind another vehicle or when in heavy traffic.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Upcoming change in direction.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided red sign means "stop."

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow-moving vehicle.
questions.answerB: Road construction/maintenance area.
questions.answerC: Traffic signal ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign is displayed on slow-moving vehicles.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead turns sharply right, then left.
questions.answerB: The road ahead turns sharply left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves to the left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: Your tire blows out while you are driving. You should:
questions.answerA: Slam on your brakes.
questions.answerB: Hold your steering wheel tightly and slow to a stop.
questions.answerC: Keep driving normally.
questions.answerD: Turn on your emergency flashers and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If you experience a tire blowout, do not immediately apply the brakes. Grip the steering wheel firmly and steer to remain in your traffic lane. Reduce your speed gradually by releasing the accelerator and staying off the brakes. Once you are moving very slowly, apply the brakes lightly and pull off the road into a safe area.

questions.question: Allow extra space in front of your vehicle when following a:
questions.answerA: Station wagon.
questions.answerB: Passenger vehicle.
questions.answerC: Motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Allow for extra space when driving behind a motorcycle. Motorcycles can stop more quickly than other vehicles can and you must have adequate room to stop if the motorcyclist brakes or falls off. Also, remember that motorcycles are difficult to see at night because they only have one tail light.

questions.question: At an intersection with stop signs on all corners, to whom must you yield the right-of-way?
questions.answerA: All drivers who got there before you.
questions.answerB: The driver on your right, regardless of who got there first.
questions.answerC: The driver on your left, regardless of who got there first.
questions.answerD: The driver across the intersection from you, regardless of who go there first.
questions.explanation: At a four-way stop, the vehicle that reaches the intersection first moves forward first. If two or more vehicles arrive at the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way.

questions.question: It is against the law to park within ____ feet of a fire hydrant.
questions.explanation: It is against the law to park within 10 feet of a fire hydrant.

questions.question: If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.answerB: Not cross the tracks until the train has completely passed.
questions.answerC: Cross the tracks at your own risk.
questions.answerD: Find an alternative route across tracks.
questions.explanation: You should look and listen for trains before crossing any railroad tracks. If an approaching train is near enough or going fast enough to be a danger, you cannot go across the tracks. This is true even if they have no signals or the signals are not working.

questions.question: A steady green traffic light at an intersection means:
questions.answerA: Increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Adjust your mirrors.
questions.answerC: You may continue through the intersection at a safe and reasonable speed, if it is clear to do so.
questions.explanation: A steady green traffic light indicates that the driver may continue through the intersection. The driver should yield to traffic or pedestrians already in the intersection and proceed when the intersection is clear.

questions.question: At a light rail intersection, always:
questions.answerA: Look both ways before crossing tracks.
questions.answerB: Pay attention and obey all traffic signals.
questions.answerC: Share the road with pedestrians and bicyclists.
questions.explanation: You should never drive around lowered crossing gates. Always look both ways before turning across train tracks and always obey signs and traffic signals. Trains share the road with motor vehicles and bicyclists.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Watch for drunk drivers.
questions.answerB: Curves ahead.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road is slippery when wet.

questions.question: Do not pass:
questions.answerA: On a hill or curve.
questions.answerB: When school bus lights are flashing.
questions.answerC: When approaching an intersection.
questions.explanation: You should never pass if there is an oncoming vehicle in the passing lane, if your view is blocked by a curve or hill, at an intersection, before or on a railroad crossing or bridge, or in any other no passing zone. Unless you are on the opposite side of a multilane roadway with a median or shared center turn lane, you may not pass a stopped school bus that has its flashing red lights activated.

questions.question: To improve visibility lowered by rain or fog, drivers should use their:
questions.answerA: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: High beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Parking lights.
questions.explanation: Use low beam headlights when driving in rain, snow, sleet, or fog. High beam headlights in adverse weather conditions lower visibility by reflecting off the precipitation and back into the driver's eyes.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the thinking of defensive drivers?
questions.answerA: They know other drivers will do the right thing.
questions.answerB: They consider what other drivers might do and are prepared to react.
questions.answerC: They expect no breaks and give none.
questions.explanation: Driving defensively means anticipating potential errors made by others and preparing to compensate for their mistakes.

questions.question: It is necessary for you to make an emergency stop. You should:
questions.answerA: Blow your horn at passing cars to let them know you have stopped.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle once you have stopped.
questions.answerC: Turn on your emergency flashers and stay in your vehicle, if you can.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop due to vehicle trouble, get off of the road and away from traffic, if possible, and turn on your emergency flashers. Stay inside your vehicle to keep yourself safe from nearby traffic.

questions.question: Only ____ can lower blood alcohol concentration (BAC) and reduce alcohol's effects on a body.
questions.answerA: Drinking caffeine
questions.answerB: Eating foods high in fat
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: The only way to sober up after drinking alcohol is to allow time for your body to eliminate the alcohol in your system. Nothing you can do, including eating and drinking, can accelerate this process.

questions.question: When used on roadways, bicycles are considered:
questions.answerA: Hazards.
questions.answerB: Vehicles.
questions.answerC: Dangerous.
questions.explanation: Bicycles are considered vehicles when used on roadways. Bicyclists and motorists are expected to follow the same rules of the road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerB: Merging traffic.
questions.answerC: Steep hill ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers of an upcoming steep hill. Drivers should adjust their speed accordingly to avoid collisions and brake damage.

questions.question: If your car begins to skid out of control, you should:
questions.answerA: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes lightly.
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, stay off the brakes. Continue to correct your steering until the vehicle is back under your control and moving safely down the road.

questions.question: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and signal arm extended, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop.
questions.answerB: Proceed at 15 mph if no children are present.
questions.answerC: Proceed at normal speed, but watch for children.
questions.explanation: If you approach a stopped school bus that has its lights flashing and arm extended, you must come to a full stop and remain stopped until the signal arm is pulled back and the bus resumes motion. This law applies whether you are traveling in the same direction as the bus or if you are approaching from the opposite side of the street.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerA: Intersection.
questions.answerB: Road curve.
questions.answerC: Right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that another road crosses the highway ahead.

questions.question: At intersections, crosswalks, and railroad crossings, you should always:
questions.answerA: Stop, listen, and proceed cautiously.
questions.answerB: Look to the sides of your vehicle to see what is coming.
questions.answerC: Slowly pass vehicles that seem to be stopped for no reason.
questions.explanation: Any time you come to a place where people may cross or enter your path, or where one line of traffic meets another, you should look to the left and right sides of your vehicle to make sure no one is coming.

questions.question: Driving at night requires increased caution because:
questions.answerA: Traffic moves faster at night.
questions.answerB: There is a larger volume of traffic at night.
questions.answerC: Drivers cannot see as well at night.
questions.answerD: Accidents occur more frequently at night.
questions.explanation: Because it is dark, drivers cannot see as well at night as they can during the day. From one half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise, or at any other time when persons or vehicles are not visible for 500 feet, drivers must use their headlights.

questions.question: What is a "No zone?"
questions.answerA: A designated no passing zone
questions.answerB: A one-way traffic area
questions.answerC: The blind spot of a large vehicle
questions.answerD: An area designated for motor vehicles
questions.explanation: "No zones" are the large blind spots around trucks and other large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should avoid lingering in "No zones."

questions.question: You are driving when it starts to sleet or snow. You should:
questions.answerA: Keep your windshield and mirrors clear.
questions.answerB: Allow additional distance between your vehicle and the vehicles that you are following.
questions.answerC: Approach all vehicles with caution.
questions.explanation: In snowy weather, keep your windshield and mirrors clear. Increase your following distance when driving in wet and cold weather because a slippery road surface will increase the distance needed for your vehicle to stop.

questions.question: If you are about to be hit from the rear, you should not:
questions.answerA: Release your seat belt.
questions.answerB: Brace yourself.
questions.answerC: Press your head against the head restraint.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle is hit from the rear while you are in forward motion, your body will be thrown backward. Brace yourself by pressing against the back of your seat and putting your head against the head restraint to prevent whiplash. Maintain a firm grip on the steering wheel and be ready to apply your brakes to avoid being pushed into another vehicle.

questions.question: Slowing down just to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary:
questions.answerA: Causes traffic congestion.
questions.answerB: Prevents rear-end collisions.
questions.answerC: Improves traffic flow by preventing collisions.
questions.explanation: Avoid "rubbernecking," or slowing down to look at collisions or anything else out-of-the-ordinary. This helps to relieve traffic congestion.

questions.question: You are driving behind a motorcycle and want to pass. You must:
questions.answerA: Stay in the right lane as much as possible because the motorcycle is small and doesn't use all of the lane.
questions.answerB: Blow your horn to make the motorcycle move onto the shoulder so that you can pass.
questions.answerC: Have your vehicle entirely in the left lane before and during the pass.
questions.explanation: When passing a motorcycle, allow a full lane to the motorcycle. Never crowd into the same lane as the motorcycle. Returning to the original lane too soon can force a rider to swerve to the right and into traffic or off the road.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident and your vehicle is blocking traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible.
questions.answerB: Not move your vehicle under any circumstances.
questions.answerC: Wait until the police arrive before moving your vehicle.
