questions.explanation: After a minor collision, move your vehicle off the traveled portion of the roadway, if possible. Do not leave the scene of an accident without identifying yourself and rendering assistance.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: No U-turn.
questions.answerB: No turning.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you may not make a U-turn. You cannot turn around to go in the opposite direction at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: Double solid yellow lines painted down the middle of the road mean:
questions.answerA: Railroad crossing ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Passing is not permitted from either direction.
questions.answerD: Passing is permitted from either direction.
questions.explanation: Double solid yellow lines in the center of the road mean that passing is not allowed from either direction. You may not cross the lines unless you are making a left turn or passing pedestrians, bicyclists, and riders of scooters or skateboards when the opposite lane is clear and you can pass safely.

questions.question: Highway markings:
questions.answerA: Are usually not important.
questions.answerB: Are only found in construction zones.
questions.answerC: Provide information for drivers.
questions.answerD: Are usually red and blue in color.
questions.explanation: Highway markings provide information for drivers. Markings help drivers correctly position their vehicles on roadways, inform drivers of safe passing zones, and warn drivers about upcoming conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: One-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Intersection ahead.
questions.answerC: Merging traffic from the right.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is merging traffic entering from the right.

questions.question: If a transit vehicle is signaling to re-enter the main roadway following a stop, you must:
questions.answerA: Honk to let them know you’re there.
questions.answerB: Move to the left lane.
questions.answerC: Yield.
questions.explanation: You must yield to any transit vehicle that is signaling to pull back onto the main roadway after it has stopped to load or unload passengers. Change lanes, slow down, or stop to allow the bus safe re-entry into traffic.

questions.question: A single broken white line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: White lines are used to separate traffic moving in the same direction. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If you have a sudden tire blowout:
questions.answerA: Use the brakes lightly.
questions.answerB: Pump the brakes.
questions.answerC: Apply the brakes firmly.
questions.explanation: If a tire suddenly goes flat while you are driving, hold the steering wheel tightly and keep the vehicle moving straight. Slow down gradually by taking your foot off the gas pedal and using the brakes lightly.

questions.question: If you are under the age of 18, to qualify for a probationary license, you must:
questions.answerA: Have an instruction permit for at least six months.
questions.answerB: Have no moving traffic violations during the previous six months.
questions.answerC: Complete an approved driver education course.
questions.explanation: To obtain a probationary license, a person under 18 must complete an approved driver education class; have had an instruction permit for at least six months; accumulate 30 hours of certified behind-the-wheel driving experience (including 10 hours at night); have had no convictions for moving violations during the previous six months; pass a driving skills test; and pay required fees.

questions.question: What is the purpose of rumble strips?
questions.answerA: They alert drivers to potential tire problems.
questions.answerB: They test a vehicle's shock absorbers.
questions.answerC: Through vibration and sound, they alert inattentive drivers to the fact that their vehicles have left the travel lane.
questions.explanation: Rumble strips create noise and vibrations to warn drowsy or inattentive drivers that they are straying off of the road or are approaching a stop sign or signal.

questions.question: Blind spots are:
questions.answerA: Spots in your vision when you become fatigued.
questions.answerB: Areas of the road that cannot be seen in a vehicle's mirrors.
questions.answerC: Traffic control devices.
questions.explanation: When changing lanes, look over your shoulder in the direction you plan to move. Check for obstructions near the rear corners of your vehicle. These areas are called “blind spots” because you cannot see them by using your mirrors.

questions.question: Regulatory signs are usually ____ and should always be obeyed.
questions.answerA: White
questions.answerB: Blue
questions.answerC: Green
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs regulate the movement of traffic. They are usually white with black markings and must always be obeyed by motorists.

questions.question: You may cross double solid yellow lines:
questions.answerA: To pass a slow-moving truck.
questions.answerB: To turn into a driveway.
questions.answerC: To pass another car.
questions.explanation: Double solid lines indicate that you may not pass or change lanes. You cannot cross the lines unless it is to turn left to enter or exit a highway, to turn into or from a driveway, or to make a U-turn (where permitted).

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Lane shifting.
questions.answerC: Low clearance.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they may encounter traffic coming from the opposite direction.

questions.question: When driving in bad weather, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Increase their speed to reach their final destination more quickly.
questions.answerB: Decrease their following distance.
questions.answerC: Increase their following distance.
questions.explanation: When driving on wet roads, drivers should increase their following distance.

questions.question: You are involved in an accident. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop immediately.
questions.answerB: Help the injured.
questions.answerC: Call the police.
questions.explanation: If involved in an accident, you should stop your vehicle immediately. If possible, move the vehicle out of the way of traffic. Call the nearest police agency and ask for an ambulance, if necessary. Do not move the injured unnecessarily, but attempt to stop severe bleeding with direct pressure. Wait for emergency vehicles to arrive.

questions.question: Compared to driving during the day, driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Less dangerous.
questions.answerB: No more or less dangerous.
questions.answerC: More dangerous.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day for several reasons. It is harder to see in the dark, you may be temporarily blinded by the glare from other vehicles' lights, and there are likely to be more drivers on the road who are tired or under the influence.

questions.question: Fatigue increases the risk of:
questions.answerA: Missing an exit.
questions.answerB: Being late for an appointment.
questions.answerC: Falling asleep behind the wheel and crashing.
questions.explanation: Fatigue causes errors related to speed and distance, increases your risk of being in a crash, and causes you to take more time to make decisions. When you are fatigued, you could fall asleep behind the wheel and crash, injuring or killing yourself or others.

questions.question: When making a turn, you must ____ your speed.
questions.answerA: Increase
questions.answerB: Maintain
questions.answerC: Vary
questions.explanation: When turning, you should reduce to a speed that allows you to maintain control of your vehicle, stay in your lane, and react to unexpected situations.

questions.question: The most effective safety restraints in a traffic crash are:
questions.answerA: Only a lap and shoulder belt.
questions.answerB: Only an airbag.
questions.answerC: Both a lap/shoulder belt and an airbag.
questions.explanation: Safety belts can double your chance of surviving a crash and more than double your chance of avoiding serious injury. Airbags, when used properly with safety belts, provide additional protection in a front-end crash. You should wear both shoulder and lap belts.

questions.question: When driving on a slippery surface, such as snow or ice:
questions.answerA: Shift to a low gear before going down steep hills.
questions.answerB: Maintain traction by following other vehicles closely.
questions.answerC: Pump your brakes to keep them from freezing.
questions.explanation: To prevent skidding on slippery surfaces, you should shift to a low gear before going down a steep hill. You should also follow farther behind the vehicle in front of you than you normally would. Quick stops should be avoided. Unless you have antilock brakes, pump the brakes to slow or stop.

questions.question: From top to bottom, the following is the proper order for traffic lights:
questions.answerA: Red, yellow, green.
questions.answerB: Red, green, yellow.
questions.answerC: Green, red, yellow.
questions.explanation: On a traffic signal arranged vertically, red is always on top and green on the bottom. When arranged horizontally, red is always on the left and green on the right.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Four-lane traffic ahead.
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of two-way traffic ahead.

questions.question: This white sign means you should not pass other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Until after you pass the sign.
questions.answerB: Unless it seems safe to do so.
questions.answerC: For any reason.
questions.explanation: A white rectangular sign indicates that you must obey the stated rule. This sign means that drivers should not pass other vehicles for any reason.

questions.question: What is a potential effect of taking a prescription drug while drinking alcohol?
questions.answerA: There will likely be no effect.
questions.answerB: It will make you more alert.
questions.answerC: It can make you unfit to drive.
questions.explanation: Legal medications, both prescription and over-the-counter, can impair your ability to drive. They can be particularly dangerous when used in combination with alcohol.

questions.question: Work zone barriers, drums, cones, and signs are used to:
questions.answerA: Make drivers angry about slow traffic.
questions.answerB: Inconvenience drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep traffic out of hazardous work zones.
questions.explanation: Work zones on highways have become increasingly dangerous places for both workers and drivers. When approaching a work zone, watch for materials such as cones, barrels, signs, large vehicles, and workers in brightly colored vests to warn you and direct you.

questions.question: Which of the following best ensures your safety and the safety of those around you when you are backing your vehicle?
questions.answerA: Honk your horn right before shifting into reverse.
questions.answerB: Check behind the vehicle before you get into the driver's seat.
questions.answerC: Check your rearview mirrors to see what is behind you.
questions.answerD: Turn up the car radio before backing up to get the attention of anyone who may be around you.
questions.explanation: Backing requires extra caution because it is difficult for drivers to see behind their vehicles. Before entering a vehicle to back up, walk to the back of the vehicle to check for children and small objects.

questions.question: A driver who is taking a non-prescription drug should:
questions.answerA: Read the labels on the drug before driving.
questions.answerB: Drink alcohol instead.
questions.answerC: Continue to drive regardless of any warning labels.
questions.explanation: Many over-the-counter medications can affect your ability to drive safely. If you take medication, even a remedy for colds or allergies that is not prescribed, check the label for warnings about its effects. If you are unsure, ask your doctor or pharmacist about driving while on the medication.

questions.question: Drivers turning left must yield to:
questions.answerA: Oncoming vehicles traveling straight or turning right.
questions.answerB: Passing cars.
questions.answerC: No one in particular.
questions.explanation: Drivers making a left turn must yield to all vehicles approaching from the opposite direction. This includes bicycles and motorcycles.

questions.question: If your car starts to skid, turn your steering wheel:
questions.answerA: To keep the front wheels straight.
questions.answerB: In the direction you want the vehicle to go.
questions.answerC: In the opposite direction of the skid.
questions.answerD: In any direction. It doesn't matter.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle goes into a skid, you should turn the steering wheel in the direction you want the vehicle to go. As soon as the vehicle begins to straighten out, turn the steering wheel back the other way.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.answerA: Use your left foot to brake.
questions.answerB: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating your vehicle.
questions.answerC: You should always brake abruptly to ensure stopping.
questions.explanation: Use your right foot for both braking and accelerating. You should apply the brakes gently with increasing pressure so that your vehicle stops gradually and smoothly.

questions.question: What is an important step in turning?
questions.answerA: Check traffic in all directions.
questions.answerB: Increase your speed.
questions.answerC: Always move to the left lane.
questions.explanation: When turning, you should look to the rear and both sides of your vehicle to ensure it is safe to proceed before making the turn. Adjust your speed to safely complete the turn.

questions.question: When is it legal to drive above the posted speed limit?
questions.answerA: Never.
questions.answerB: When you don't see any other traffic in your lane.
questions.answerC: When you are passing another vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is illegal to ever exceed the posted speed limit, even for the purpose of passing another vehicle.

questions.question: You see pedestrians near the road. You should:
questions.answerA: Sound your horn and maintain your speed.
questions.answerB: Speed up to clear the area quickly.
questions.answerC: Slow down and pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Watch for any pedestrian who may cross your path. If you see pedestrians near the road where you are driving, slow down and be prepared to stop, if necessary.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you:
questions.answerA: Are approaching a railroad crossing and should prepare to stop.
questions.answerB: Will always stop at the upcoming railroad crossing.
questions.answerC: Should stop and wait for a signal before crossing the railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that you are approaching a railroad crossing. You must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Wait for any trains to pass before you proceed.

questions.question: What is the only medically proven method of removing alcohol or other drug combinations from your system?
questions.answerA: Breathe in some fresh air.
questions.answerB: Give your body time.
questions.answerC: Drink coffee.
questions.explanation: Alcohol takes effect quickly and is slow to leave your system. Cold showers, black coffee, and exercise will do nothing to reduce a person's blood alcohol content (BAC). The only way to lower your BAC is to wait.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Slow down; curving road ahead.
questions.answerB: Slow down and do not use your brakes.
questions.answerC: Slow down; slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that the road ahead becomes slippery when wet.

questions.question: When driving in fog, it is best to drive with:
questions.answerA: High beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Low beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: Use low beam headlights when driving in fog, rain, or snow. High beams may reflect off of the weather and make visibility even poorer.

questions.question: In inclement weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Steer off the road.
questions.answerB: Drive in a low gear.
questions.answerC: Steer and brake smoothly.
questions.explanation: When driving during unfavorable weather conditions, avoid slamming on the brakes and making sharp, quick turns. These behaviors will make controlling your vehicle in inclement weather even more difficult.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Two-way traffic.
questions.answerB: Change in direction ahead.
questions.answerC: School zone and crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign informs drivers that they are leaving a divided roadway and approaching a two-way highway.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Divided highway.
questions.answerB: Railroad warning.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead.

questions.question: If you must park your vehicle in an area not usually used for parking:
questions.answerA: Park with your reverse lights on.
questions.answerB: Make sure your vehicle is visible to drivers approaching from any direction.
questions.answerC: Park five feet from the curb.
questions.explanation: Drivers are responsible for making sure their vehicles do not become hazards after they have been parked. Wherever you park, make sure your car is visible to drivers approaching from any direction.

questions.question: When being passed by another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Brake hard.
questions.answerB: Maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerC: Speed up.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you must yield to the passing vehicle and not increase your speed. Allow the vehicle to safely merge back into your lane.

questions.question: You may drink alcoholic beverages in a vehicle on a public highway:
questions.answerA: As long as you aren't driving.
questions.answerB: If you are riding in the back seat.
questions.answerC: If you are riding in the back of a pick-up truck.
questions.explanation: It is against the law to consume or possess any alcoholic beverage while on a public road or sidewalk. Additionally, storing an open alcoholic beverage container in an area of a motor vehicle normally occupied by the driver or passenger is prohibited on any public road.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp right turn ahead.
questions.answerB: A road joins from the right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead turns sharply right then sharply left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then sharply to the left.

questions.question: If you see orange construction signs and cones on a freeway, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow down because the lane ends ahead.
questions.answerB: Be prepared for workers and equipment ahead.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and maintain your current speed.
questions.explanation: As you enter a work zone, signs and message boards will warn you of workers, slow-moving equipment, and/or closed lanes ahead. You should reduce your speed and be prepared to slow down or stop.

questions.question: If you are driving on the interstate and pass your exit, you should:
questions.answerA: Quickly cut across traffic to make your turn.
questions.answerB: Make a U-turn to go back to the exit.
questions.answerC: Continue driving and use the next exit.
questions.answerD: Put your vehicle in reverse to go back to the exit.
questions.explanation: Don’t make a last-minute turn into an exit. If you pass your exit, you must go to the next one.

questions.question: If you are stopped and the officer suspects you have been drinking, you:
questions.answerA: May not refuse the BAC test.
questions.answerB: May refuse the BAC test if you haven't been drinking.
questions.answerC: May refuse the BAC test if you think you will fail.
questions.explanation: Wisconsin has an Implied Consent Law, which means that you must comply if a police or traffic officer asks you to take an alcohol test.

questions.question: You must yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle that is using its siren and flashing lights by:
questions.answerA: Driving as closely to the right edge of the road as possible and stopping.
questions.answerB: Moving into the right lane and driving slowly until it has passed.
questions.answerC: Stopping immediately, even if you are within an intersection.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren and flashing lights. Do this by driving to the right edge of the road and stopping, taking care not to stop in an intersection. You may move again after the emergency vehicle has passed.

questions.question: When arriving to an uncontrolled intersection at the same time as vehicles to your right and left, you should:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your left.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on your right.
questions.answerC: Wait until there are no vehicles at the intersection before proceeding.
questions.explanation: If multiple vehicles arrive at the same time to an intersection that is not controlled by signs or signals, the driver on the right has the right-of-way. Drivers should then proceed in the order that they arrive to the intersection.

questions.question: You may drive around the gates at a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: When the train has passed.
questions.answerB: Under no circumstances.
questions.answerC: When the lights have stopped flashing.
questions.answerD: When other drivers drive around the gates.
questions.explanation: You are required to stop at all railroad crossings when signals warn of an approaching train. These signals may include flashing red lights, a lowered crossing gate, a flagger signaling, or a train’s audible signal of warning. Do not attempt to go around a lowered gate.

questions.question: To prepare for anything coming up on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerA: Continually scan the entire road and all roadsides.
questions.answerB: Stare straight ahead at all times.
questions.answerC: Drive with your left foot resting lightly on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Maintain focus toward the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: Your ability to handle dangerous traffic situations depends largely on searching for and identifying problems before meeting them. Looking far ahead of your vehicle does not mean you should simply stare at the center of the road. You need to continually scan the entire road, including the sides of the road.
